Some merchants from Nazair bought fifteen barrels of water at market! And they paid as if it were Est Est!
Calm down, please!
Disperse! The exhibition of the Reginald d'Aubry monument will remain closed until further notice!
Closed?! Why, we rode an entire day to see it! You're a cheat, sir!
And we paid good coin for the tickets! Give it back!
Your tickets remain valid! You must merely wait patiently for the exhibition to reopen!
Arbiter
I thank you… So tasty, oh so good.
Mm, hm, tasty, mm, so, mmm, wonderful. Thank you.
Shh, easy, not gonna hurt you.
Eat… I must… eat!
I'll take you someplace safe.
Regis' Bloodlust

When Geralt first agreed to look into problems at some vineyards in Toussaint, he had not expected these matters to occupy him for long. When the witcher then learned Count Crespi had provoked the quarrel between the vineyard owners, an end to the mess was finally in sight. The ducal clerk was clearly pleased to see Liam de Coronata and Matilda Vermentino join forces. And he agreed to transfer Belgaard to them jointly on one condition - they would first need to resolve the troubles at their home estates.

Not monsters, not bandits - Geralt feared nothing! He quickly tended to the problems at Coronata and Vermentino, then set off to see the co-owners of the newly formed consortium to collect the reward they had promised him.
Help Liam and Matilda's consortium.
Return to Liam and Matilda.
Wine Wars: Consorting

Not all knights errant in Toussaint were embodiments of virtue, but if I had to choose one among them who did personify their chivalric creed, it would be Palmerin de Launfal. He is all the more admirable for the fact that, years ago, he was no stranger to the pleasures of eating, drinking and making merry in a variety of fashions. With time, however, he abandoned vice and drew closer to the knightly ideal. Geralt realized this when Palmerin came to him as an envoy from Anna Henrietta. The old-fashioned and somewhat naive knight immediately made a good impression on him, for while he did take formalities and courtesies a tad too seriously, he was anything but pompous or grandiose.
Palmerin de Launfal
So? What's there to think about? These are very, very, very fine vintages.
Remember, I just returned from Nazair!
Am I a Black One, a Nilfgaardian? Are we at some stall in some market in Riedbrune?

No! You are in my shop. Now, Toussaintois who know the difference between good wine and drowner urine, this is the shop they come to. Now my wine, I will take the Beauclair challenge against that piss from Nazair any day of the week!
A bold statement.
Achoo!
Unbelievable…
Mornin'!
Bugger off.
Where you walkin'?!
Save yourselves!
I don't want to dieeee!
Beggar
This has gotten dull…
You like this? I mean, really?
Ehh, not this again…
Oh, she's got the loveliest… Huh?! What?!
Can't you see I'm thinking?! Try not to interrupt,
Looking to brawl?
Surrender!
I'm too young to die!
Aaaargh!
Ugh, if I weren't just a lowly guardsman…
She looked at me, all right, looked right at me!
Hey! You!

Looked like a bruxa, but that was no bruxa…
– fragment of a conversation between the ealdorman of Falkoane and a witcher.

Alps are vampires that resemble bruxae in appearance. They are called phantoms by some, a name which fits well enough, for like phantoms they haunt and torment men. They usually take on the form of a woman, though they can also appear as animals. They are most often found prowling near villages. They attack at night and are most active when the moon is full. Alp saliva can make one fall asleep, and when applied to a sleeping man, can invoke horrible nightmares. Some suggest they are the cause of legends about men who go to sleep healthy and are found in the morning white as snow, not a drop of blood in their veins.

In combat alps display supernatural speed and incredible (even by vampire standards) stamina. One must aim one’s sword with great precision, for alps are unequaled in the art of evading blows. The Yrden Sign is recommended, for it weakens an alp’s defenses. Another strategy is to drink the Black Blood potion, for alps suck the blood of their victims to deprive them of strength and regenerate their own powers.

Unlike bruxae, alps cannot turn invisible, yet like bruxae, they emit a shrieking noise whose shock wave can incapacitate. Their greatest asset is their agility and they can leap with uncanny lightness that appears to border on the power of flight. When in human form, they easily blend in with the surrounding community, which makes them very dangerous indeed.
Alps
King Cormorant, Sire, accept this offering we bring. Prithee cast upon us your merciful eye and bare before us its secrets.
As the moon its heavenly course doth trace, in my demesne I await that moment of grace,
When a soul of good or ill repute, brings me a gift, fitting tribute…
A key.
Hey! Wait!
Stop! It's important!
He's ruined the game!
Disgraceful!
Why, you bumbotched wretch!
Don't cry, dear. The duchess will hear of this.
This is an outrage!
Welcome to the court of King Cormorant.
I vow on the crane that I shall fight with honor. And I dedicate this fight to you, my Lady.
I accept your vow.
I vow upon the crane--
I believe I've made myself clear. I shall not grant you leave. It's out of the question.
My Lady, I have a fierce wish to fight fiercely in your name and fiercely ask your permission to so do.
My permission thus I grant you, sir.
Master witcher! What luck to happen upon you!
Got work for me? A new contract?
Of the contract in question you acquitted yourself beautifully years past, on your last sojourn in Beauclair.
I was in a bit of a bind at the time… Do you remember? Yet I swore a solemn vow to pay you in full one day.
Guess it rings a bell…
Sadly, you went on your way before I could settle matters with you. So I took your coin and placed it in an account for safekeeping.
Hm. What kind of account?
A savings account. At Cianfanelli Bank. You need but walk in and withdraw. The sum must be rather substantial by now…
Thanks. Head over there first chance I get.
Good to see you again.
Ah, the serendipity! I'm so glad you're back!
I'm listening.
Out with it.
I wonder how much a witcher pays in taxes…
In fact, I wonder if a witcher pays any taxes at all…
Hmmm?
Ta ra ri rrra ra…
There we are. Merten wrote a prayer on the back of the diagram.
Seems he left the prison, came here, then went on to the temple…
Slips of paper all over, prayer on each one. Maybe Merten left one, too.
The cave Merten mentioned. Need to look around.
Looks like the place mentioned in the journal. Should search it.
Why, that's…
Ooh!
Her Grace! The duquessa!
He was here before, years ago. I saw him then.
Who is he?
A monster slayer.
The witcher bested all our knights at the tourney! Must have mountain-sized stones! Hahaha!
Thank you, master witcher! Loth Halfbreed's hanse, now that was a mean bunch of harlotsbroods!
What are your needs, master?
Here, master witcher! Over here!
Master witcher?
Well met!
Master witcher, restrain yourself…
Hey, slow, now!
Eh. I don't know.
What? You want to fight?
I weewee on everything.
Emperor - I weewee on him. Knights - weewee on them. Guard - you bet I wee on them. I weewee on the whole bleeding duchy!

Intending to take a refreshing dip in Seidhe Llygad, Geralt happened on a corpse. Unsurprisingly, this quelled his desire to dive into the lake's shimmering waters. Yet on the corpse, which proved to be that of a suicide, he found a letter…

The letter spoke of the love that had bloomed between Selina and Bruce - two famed Beauclairois cat burglars. It also detailed the sad end of the duo's story. But any tale of burglars is a tale of their loot. Always a big spender and thus ever in need of coin, the witcher resolved to find the hidden treasure.
Geralt discovered he was not the lone prospector for the treasure Selina had left behind. So he quickly cut down his competitors, a band of grave robbers, and made off with the loot.
While exploring the catacombs beneath the city cemetery, Geralt ran into a crew of grave robbers. Giggling and cursing, the band of robbers swarmed the witcher, which ended tragically for them…

On the gang leader's rapidly cooling corpse, Geralt found an interesting letter from which he learned about Selina's Gang and a treasure that supposedly lay concealed in the tomb of a now dead but once famous woman burglar. Yet to get at the treasure, the witcher needed a key.
Bruce, Selina's erstwhile lover, had the key. Grieving after having lost his beloved and unable to bear life alone, Bruce had chosen suicide, jumped in the lake and drowned.

Content to have found the key, Geralt returned to the gloomy catacombs and unlocked a chest full of valuables.. Since none of the members of the gang remained alive, the witcher could take all the wealth for himself with a clear conscience, then set off in search of new adventures.
Read the letter.
Find the treasure hidden in the cemetery.
Read the letter the grave robber was carrying.
Search the shore of the lake near Orlémurs Cemetery.
The Last Exploits of Selina's Gang

Beann'shies howl and shriek, and if you hear their cry, you can know you’ll join the ranks of the dead that night.
– beggar from Dun Dâre

Old gossips claim beann'shies are the spirits of women stuck between life and death due to traumatic experiences. Their wails and howls are considered ill omens of imminent, inevitable death, though they are said not to attack the living themselves. Most often they appear in the form of pale, tear-streaked women with shriveled faces and wrinkled, corpse-like bodies.

Beann'shies are wraiths which use their piercing cries to wake the dead to fight their foes. Their cries can additionally stun enemies, making them easy targets for direct attacks.

Beann'shies can regenerate, but this does not mean they cannot be defeated – they are vulnerable to silver and wraith oil as well as the witcher Signs (though they are known to be resistant to the Signs’ critical effects).

When fighting a beann'shie, there is no point using bombs or bolts, for they will do the wraith no damage.
Beann'shies
Bank Clerk
Boy
A witcher.
A witcher. And I'd advise you to go back where you came from.
I thought witchers defend men from monsters, not cheats from justice!
Need to talk to the boy.
You can chat with him all you like - after we tan his hide! So stand down!
Not your concern.
All you need to know is, long as I'm here, you're not gonna touch the boy.
Is that so? Then we'll come find him once you're gone.
Try it, and I'll find you.
Is that a threat?!
Yep. Leave the kid be and piss off.
Oh, no! No northern sheepdiddler insults us!
We'll pummel the swine first, then spank the piglet! Get him!
Not gonna happen.
Won't it? Well, then we will thrash you as well. Which is all the same to me.
His father. And you won't touch him. I won't let you.
Oh, poppycock! I knew his father! A grifter, a cheat, just like his brood!
I'll teach him honesty! He'll not leave muck at our shop door just to draw patrons to his own stall!
So back away, drifter!
His father.
Leave him alone.
Just who the spit are you?
So how would you explain it?! Whether it pours for a week or the sun bakes our pates, we've always mud up to our ankles here!
You can't blame me for Beauclair's fickle weather.
Fickle weather?! I've seen you! You empty your chamber pot in front of our shop each morn. So folk will dirty their boots, go to you to get them cleaned!
A far-fetched conspiracy theory, sirs…
I'll conspire to welt your bum with my belt! Come here!
Caught you, you little fart!
Whatever's the problem, kind sirs?
This mud! Rain or shine, it's always here! And now we know why!
You dump your waste in front of our shop! We saw you!
Oh my, sirs, you really ought to go easy on the wine.
Bootblacks don't usually work nights. Need to come back during the day.
We'll break your legs, vagrant!
Teach you to help scofflaws and cheats!
Not now, Geralt… I could not move a step without your assistance.
Just and true, the knight returned, from his days at war, yet the lass, for whom he'd pined and yearned, had married days before.
To you, my dear, I've sworn my heart. My soul's sweet sovereign, my queen, thou art…
Sir?
Yes, sir?
Ahem… Uh, so, I'll be at the boat landing near the palace… waiting for Regis there… Mind telling him?
[Stay here.]
[Go to meet Regis.]
You've met with Orianna. How did it go?
Yeah, I know. You'd still prefer to free Syanna - for Dettlaff's sake.
For the sake of you both.
Oh, please. Orphanage, what happened there - his fault, plain and simple. City gutters are overflowing with blood - that's his doing, too. And you're worried somebody might've hurt his feelings?

To meet the Unseen Elder is to face mortal danger - I've said so all along and never in jest. You are a friend, a dear friend. I'd rather you not risk your neck unnecessarily - I think it's natural, I think it's obvious. Obviously natural. Especially when we've an alternative. An entirely reasonable one.
Time we were on our way. Listen, I need to sail there… Coming with, or would you rather float over as a puff of fog?
I'd not be able to talk as a puff. And, as you know, talking is something I very much like to do.
Mhm. At length and in detail. Let's go.
Unseen Elder - let's find him.
Need a little time to prepare, now. Wait here for me?
I shall await you at our destination, if it's all the same to you. So, see you… though, try not to make me wait too long.
Need some time to prepare.
I'm a witcher, Regis. I don't cut deals with monsters, I cut monsters down. And I don't give a damn about the risks.
Hm, well… I understand. I'll not mention it again.
Thanks.
Won't change my mind, Period.
Ugh… fine, have it your way. We'll free Syanna. If we can even figure out where she's being held, 'cause--
I've looked into it already.
Oh yeah?
Mhm. I managed to convince Damien to help us. He claims Syanna was last seen in the palace playroom.
A playroom? For children? What'd the duchess do, lock her in a dollhouse?
Perhaps, I don't know. We must see for ourselves. Come.
Ugh, you've worn me down, Regis. Fine, have it your way. Playroom - let's go.
Excellent decision.
Time'll tell.
Fine. Let's go find Syanna.
Perhaps we could give it one more try? I mean, we were so close…
Mhm. But I changed my mind.
Yet perhaps you'd care to reconsider once more?
Don't push it, Regis. Orphanage - Dettlaff's fault. City gutters are overflowing with blood. Also his doing. And you're worried somebody might've hurt his feelings? Come on.
In meeting the Unseen Elder you will risk all. You cannot be certain to leave with your life. Yet if we meet Dettlaff's demand, the killing will cease at once.
Not well.
Oh? Did she not divulge where you might find the Unseen?
No, she did. Also divulged her hunger for the blood of small children.
I admit I'd heard rumors, but… preferred to lend them no credence.
Rather not talk about it. Cave's west of town, other side of the lake. That's where we need to go.
I see. I'm prepared to set out at any time, but…
So, you decided to talk to Orianna after all… How did you fare?
Greetings, Geralt.
Ought we begrudge fair-faced ladies their airs,
When trees in high canopies hide the best apples and pears?
I'll be your long-haired lover from Novigrad, and I'll do anything you say.
Will you invite me back to your vineyard?
Ha ha ha ha!
Tra la lee la!
All possible punishments have visited us…
When the duquessa laughs, it's no laughing matter!
Are you still here?! But you're the very reason the duquessa's dead!
That the Guard puts up with a butcher in our midst…
Your armor must've chafed the sense out of you!
Pop around the corner, see if you're not there.
Ehh, go stick a carrot up your nose.
Beetrooting lummox!
Think you could craft something for me?
Craft something for me?
Wanna place a special order. Think you can handle it?
How special is it to be?
Got these diagrams. Take a look, judge for yourself.
Tsk, alas. It's black magic to me. But I know one who could help you.
You must try Lafargue. His smithy lies near the Metinna Gate.
Think you can decipher these diagrams?
Farewell.
No. See you later!
Farewell.
Show me your wares.
Show me what you have.
Oh, look! A witcher graces my humble forge.
The best steel in all of Toussaint! Take a gander.
Eh, bumbersnatch. Happens to the best. It serves me right for challenging a stranger. To have such a deck, ah….
So long.
Hm, I expected more of you. But, I suppose you put in an honest effort. You know what they say - tables are like day-old fish, apt to turn on you when you least expect it.
Right…
I shall tell you this much… when first I heard Maid Matilda had forged a partnership with the ever slippery Liam, well, I near popped a cork!
But once it was revealed the dingledong had not, in fact, been responsible for our woes, I thought to myself…
I suppose it's about time Maid Matilda found a mister, is it not?
Greetings, Geralt!
Craft something for me?
Craft something for me, can you?
Here we are. Is there some way I might help you?
All right. What do you have?
Show me your wares?
Thanks, see you later.
Take care.
Bandits aren't your only problem, don't think…
Vineyard 's glory days seem like a thing of the past…
It's seen better times, true. For bandits are not our only problem. Enormous yellow parasites, their ever-growing plague, we also must contend with.
Maid Matilda tries her best, but when folk fear to go out and work, what is she to do?
I thank you again for your aid! Till we meet at Vermentino.
Fine, lead the way.
Fine, let's go.
Go ahead. I'll stop by when I'm in the area.
I'll come by later.
I owe you my life, unknown knight. How are you dubbed?
Dubbed Geralt. Geralt of Rivia.
My thanks, Sir Geralt! The scallywags sought to demolish our herb garden, you see! I thought, I shall take a hammer, scare the rabble off, but…
To my great chagrin, there were too many and I, I failed!
Ehh, there's no use crying over spilt wine. Come with me to Vermentino, I'll patch up your armor or pound the anvil to fulfill some other need you might have.
Help! Save me!
And with that we're safe! All thanks to the witcher!
Have you found de Peyrac-Peyran?
Not yet.
Perhaps we should stop the diversion after all.
We've searched for Milton this whole time. And we've nothing to show for it.
Living Statue
Raven
We're to kiss the ground you walk on, is that it? But you just did your diddly witcherly duty!
Mean to hunt the Beast?
So, Snow White, what's new?
Heighdie-heighdie-heighdie-ho!
Where there is smoke, there is fire!
Oh, you are so bimbazzled…
I'll crack, thwack and sgack you!
Why the wide stride? A keepsake from your stay in the clink?
A group of rogues walks amidst the trees, willies aswinging betwixt their knees!
When I was a little lad, my stones stank awfully bad.
Hoping it would cure the smell, I dipped my pouch in a well…
Imlerith
Tell me about yourself?
Doing a great job here…
For a woman, you mean?
For anyone. Learned long ago not to judge men and women by different standards.

That's nice to hear. I'd dreamt of running this vineyard since I was a child. My mother was a wash maid, found a position here. She would bring me along and while she laundered the linens I would play with the cats.
Lady Vermentino always fed me sweet grapes. And for a few brief moments I would imagine she was my mother, even wish it so.
When my real mother passed away, the Vermentinos took me in. They had no children of their own.
Thus I became Matilda de Vermentino. In the end I got my dream, though at times I'm still tortured by the thought that my secret wish might've brought about my birth mother's death.
Witcher! How good of you to come! Any news?
Tell me about yourself?
Come from a long line of vintners, don't you.
Yes, my great-grandpapa planted the first seeds at Coronata. Yet my father made the vineyard bloom.
He had hoped one of my elder brothers would take up the hoe and grape knife. Alas, he proved a tyrant. All eight fled, wanting nothing to do with winemaking.
I graduated Oxenfurt Academy and returned home to find myself up to my ears in work. I set my own plans aside, then abandoned them. But I regret nothing. I've grown to love the trade.
Witcher, you're here! Any news?
You can start operating normally.
Shouldn't have any more problems with the vineyard. You can start operating normally again.
Splendid. And thus, officially, by the power vested in me, I grant you title to the Belgaard Vineyard and trust that you shall restore it to its former glory, mademoiselle.
I shall do everything in my power.
Thank you. You're truly worth your weight in gold! Ah, if my mother could see this… She always wanted a better future for me, and now, thanks to you, I might actually have one.
Here. Your reward as agreed.
Thanks. And good luck.
All's well at Belgaard. Took care of the problems.
Splendid. And thus, officially, by the power vested in me, I grant you title to the Belgaard Vineyard and trust that you shall make good use of its grounds and resources.
Thank you! Ah, I can already taste this vineyard's first young wines… Scrumptious.
Don't let the vapors go to your head…
Witcher - your pay. The amount we agreed. Now forgive me, I must get to work, look over the suppliers' bids. Liam was to do it, but he's busy, as you can see…
Ehh, I fear this will not be an easy partnership… I just hope we don't end up killing one another. All the same, I thank you for your help.
Good luck. So long.
Tended to Belgaard's problems. Vineyard should be in as good a shape as ever.
Splendid. And thus, officially, by the power vested in me, I grant you title to the Belgaard Vineyard and trust that you shall make good use of its grounds and resources.
Excellent! Ah, I can already smell the grapes ripening in the sun…
We shan't forget what you did for us. Here, your pay.
But that's not all. You must come back and see us shortly. We've a surprise in store for you.
I'll do that. Farewell.
Tended to Belgaard's problems. Think you can start producing wine.
Splendid. And thus, officially, by the power vested in me, I grant you title to the Belgaard Vineyard and trust that you shall prove a wise, interested, resolute steward.
Thank you!
You've saved my derriere! Ah, fortune's smiled on me since you showed up. While you were out there, I found a case with my father's notes in the cellar.

He left a whole tome's-worth, discussing which vines do best in this climate. Now that the vineyard can operate normally at last, for the first time in a long while I feel everything is falling into place. This is for you.
Thanks. And good luck.
Farewell.
Farewell.
Farewell.
Vineyard can start operating normally again.
Decidedly too dear, that.
Could you shave a whisker off?
Ahem, my desire for Belgaard to pass into capable hands was no idle whim. For the vineyard's fallen upon hard times since its previous owner's demise.
I have been told of workers dying on their rounds, monsters prowling about… Before anyone can call this home, they will have to deal with these… inconveniences. That is the minister's wish.
More work for me, I guess…
If you're willing, I'd gladly accept your help.
Oh, sorry, I can't possibly afford that. I hope you'll help me all the same.
A fair price.
Need to think this over.
Got some other things on my plate. Need to think this through. Might look in on you if I'm in the area.
I will be very grateful if you do.
It certainly seems so. But if we're to make anything of this partnership, in itself a difficult notion, we must be able to work, without hindrance or threat.
So? Will you help our fragile consortium?
If you're willing, we'll gladly accept your help.
Let's talk about my pay.
I can help, sure, but I won't work for free.
Too much. Definitely too much.
A bit less? Is that out of the question?
Fine. We have a deal.
No, too much. Take what we offer, please, we can afford no more.
I'll get to work.
More or less already agreed, I guess…
Phew, that's a weight off my chest, I must say. Your reward shall be fair, I promise.
Sure. I'll help you.
Lemme give it a think.
I'll look into it if I pass by. All I can promise.
It's something, thank you.
Really? You'd help? Agree and I shall pay you exceedingly well.
That's much too much.
A bit less, could you? I'm no millionaire.
Let's talk about my pay.
Need to talk about my fee, first.
That certainly sounds reasonable. Agreed.
I've a dire need, and you seek to take advantage. Take what I offer, for truly I can afford no more.
Don't know that I wanna get any more involved. One thing I can promise - if I come across anything dangerous, I'll definitely react.
Naturally, I wouldn't ask for anything more.
Need to think it over.
I'll help.
Ah, in for a copper, in for a crown… Yeah, I'll help.
Thank you.
Come with me, please. We've formalities to see to.
I am right behind you.
Miss, come with me, please? We've formalities to attend to.
Of course.
More or less agreed already…
Excellent! You truly are a boon from the heavens.
I'll help.
Let's talk about my pay.
Can do it, but not for free.
Nilfgaardian Officer
You're a right dishy piece of-- Urgh. I'm going to spew.
Blrghfgh… Blech… Ptooey.
That tipple of yours, Geralt… Fan-fuffing-tastic!
Were wine from poopoo pressed, its wondrous flavor would still be best. Heehee.
Tweedle-dee, tweedle-dum, your old man is your mum! Teeheehee.
Wight
[PL] Szkielet
Dreadfully sorry.
Those were the days…
I've always dreamt of traveling to the North…
I imagine you've been all over the world, Sir Witcher.
What's new in the North?
Have you seen the Skellige Isles?
Bandit Leader

The Duchy of Toussaint is the homeland of wine and knights errant. And just like grapes need the sun to ripen, so do knights errant need a certain amount of encouragement to complete their missions. Geralt, while not a knight and not really known to be errant, decided nevertheless to jump into one's boots and try to earn a few coppers.

Who would have thought that, in a land flowing with milk and honey, Geralt would happen across a settlement in desperate and urgent need of a witcher's blade! Luckily our hero always kept his at the ready and soon managed to rescue at least a dozen people. Afterwards... he gave it some thought and concluded there might be someone around willing to pay him for his trouble.

Who would have thought that, in a land flowing with milk and honey, Geralt would happen across a knight in desperate and urgent need of a witcher's blade! Luckily our hero always kept his at the ready and soon managed to rescue the poor man. Afterwards... he gave it some thought and concluded there might be someone around willing to pay him for his trouble.

Who would have thought that, in a land flowing with milk and honey, Geralt would happen across a person in desperate and urgent need of a witcher's blade! Luckily our hero always kept his at the ready and soon managed to rescue the merchant. Afterwards... he gave it some thought and concluded there might be someone around willing to pay him for his trouble.

Who would have thought that, in a land flowing with milk and honey, Geralt would happen across the lair of a group of ruthless, cold-blooded bandits. Luckily our hero always kept his steel sword at the ready and soon had dispatched this "hanse" of dangerous delinquents. Afterwards... he gave it some thought and concluded there might be someone around willing to pay him for his trouble.
Geralt completed all the contracts the camerlengo had to offer him. The reward he received was not quite what he had expected, true, but valuable all the same.

Geralt came across an altogether typical looking notice – someone was looking for the help of knights or other "strongmen." He concluded he met the above-stated requirements and set off for Knights Dormant Square to meet with the ducal camerlengo.

Geralt's efforts would in fact not go unrewarded. He found a contract on a notice board in which the ducal camerlengo promised a reward for the help of "knights or other strongmen." The witcher concluded he met the above-stated requirements and set off for Knights Dormant Square to meet with the ducal camerlengo.
Complete the contracts you took on from the camerlengo.
[Optional] Go see the ducal camerlengo to collect your pay.
Go see the ducal camerlengo about your reward for fulfilling the contracts.
Go see the ducal camerlengo about your pay.
See if there is anything on the notice boards about a contract for helping out around the region.
Check the notice board for a contract for helping out around the region.
Go to the ducal camerlengo to learn the details of the contract.
Deal with the vampires swarming the city.
Knight for Hire
Shepherd
Dettlaff van der Eretein, you do not know us, but we know you… to be a vampire. We know also of your weakness for the wench they call Rhenawedd.

Now you know this. We shall chain her down and let rats feed on her. We shall flay the skin from her flesh… Yet you can save her. You need but travel to Beauclair, where you shall slay five men in the manner we prescribe.
You must complete the killing in three days. Fail, and the next letter you receive will contain a memento of your failure - your beloved's finger.
There you have it. Proof positive Dettlaff killed not of his own accord. A blackmailer's sunk his claws into him.
Blackmailer - any idea who it could be?
Any idea what it could be? Dettlaff have any enemies?
Indeed, Dettlaff gains foes occasionally, but they never live long.
One might've managed to evade him.
Possible in theory… but I know of none. It would have to be someone devilishly dangerous. As you well know, having faced Dettlaff yourself.
Whoever it is, it is someone new.
Who's Rhenawedd?
Why'd he believe she'd gone missing?
Why'd he think that? Any signs or clues to that effect?

None to be found. Apparently she disappeared one day. Her belongings disappeared with her. Not a scenario one associates with kidnapping. In my humble opinion, she left on her own, scared off, perhaps, by a bout of Dettlaff's rage that revealed his other, more monstrous side.
Untrue.
Not how I'd put it. Doubt it's how the duchess will see it, either.
I trust you to convince her. And then…
What? Go on, don't be shy. See you've got all figured out. Including the grin I gotta wear.
It's a rather bold plan, but… were we to find Rhenawedd, we would strip the blackmailers of their hold on Dettlaff.
That's one idea…
Hm. Could be worth a shot, but… what about Dettlaff? He gonna go on killing while I'm out searching for his lover?
He will not. I shall convince him to stay his hand, assure him you're a friend seeking to help. I'll await him here - he's sure to return sooner or later.
Think he'll listen?
He will.
Oughta wait with you, maybe.
No. He'll sense you from a mile off, simply fail to appear. I'd better stay alone, you must trust me on this.
Fine. Need to report to the duchess, first.
So be it. We'll await you here. Dettlaff and I both.
Actually, it is. Dettlaff's being manipulated. Some lunatic's turned him into a tool, making him kill.
So it would seem… But this illuminates a path of action for us. We must find Rhenawedd, render the blackmail senseless. The lunatic or tics will thus lose hold on Dettlaff.
True.
Let's sum up what we know.
Seems Dettlaff's being blackmailed. Someone's been feeding him his victims' names.
All noted down using one and the same Nazairi ink. And not in his handwriting.
Not much…
But enough to ascertain Dettlaff's innocence. Clearly.
Let's sum up what we know.
Blackmailer, curious about him.
Blackmailer - kinda curious who it could be…
Why is that?
Regis… Somebody kidnapped a vampire's lover - bold to begin with. Now they're forcing the vampire to kill, a vampire you yourself insist is no murderer. Blackmailer's skilled, someone special.
Hm. Astute. Now that I think of it, I'm beginning to wonder if…
It's not one of your kind? Another vampire?
Precisely. The plot thickens.
Just a hypothesis. Wouldn't set my heart on it till we know more.
Right you are.
Look, slips of paper, name on each…
Count Crespi, Count du Lac, Milton de Peyrac-Peyran, Count de la Croix…
Dettlaff's victims, one and all. But that's not his hand.
Must've come from whoever wrote the letter.
All of it written using the same ink.
See the color? Ink was dyed with cinnabarite. Rare mineral, pretty much found only in…
Nazair. But I fear it means very little - anyone could have imported such ink.
Fair enough. Still worth remembering.
Look, this slip is stained.
With wine. Not much to go on, either - especially not in Beauclair.
Perhaps… Yet perhaps also worth remembering.
Dettlaff could've written all that.
Dettlaff's handwriting - seen many samples?
A handful. But mind telling me why you ask?
Listen, I know you wanna believe he's somehow not responsible, but maybe you're just wrong. Could be he himself wrote those names out, stained that slip with wine…
No, Geralt. I know him. In a fit of rage, out of passion - I could believe he could kill. But murder, a series, no less, planned out? It's simply not him.
A hideout in the city, learning his victim's habits, noting down their names… No. Someone is controlling him. Of this I am certain.
Right, so someone's blackmailing him - we know that. Still have no idea who. Need to look around some more.
Still got nothing, basically. Need to look around some more.
Let's get to work.
Need more clues. Keep looking.
Even if Rhenawedd did abandon him that time, looks like someone's actually kidnapped her this time.
Hard to argue with that. And hard to foresee what he's prepared to do to free her, get her back.
He's prepared to kill, that's clear.
As would you be for Yennefer. He kills for he cares for her deeply, and that blood, those individuals… they mean nothing to him.
Yeah, I get it now. He's out to rescue a female from his pack.
Exactly.
Looks like somebody actually kidnapped her this time.
Dettlaff ever try to look for her?
Dettlaff ever try to find her? I mean, if she was that important…
Higher vampires have their ways. All kinds. Should've been easy as pie for him.
Geralt, as you rightly noted, we are vampires, not miracle workers.
He searched, for months on end before giving up. Clearly Rhenawedd knew him all too well, enough to cover her tracks, leave no way for him to find her.
Dettlaff have trouble letting go, accepting that she'd left him?
Is that so hard to believe? Do you know no humans who've struggled with just such a thing? And Dettlaff is so much more emotional than most humans.
Not only was she his beloved, his lover, his mate. She was a member of his pack. And one never leaves one's pack voluntarily.
Take it you have your doubts.

I know humans better than he does. Their capacity to be disloyal, dishonest. I also know she took her things - not something one associates with the kidnapped or those who disappear against their will.

I'll save you the trouble of asking - no, I don't know why she left. I can, however, hazard a guess that Dettlaff grew angry one day, showed another, more monstrous side. Dettlaff's anger could frighten anyone off, though most who see it get no chance to flee.
What do you think happened to her?
Who's Rhenawedd?
His one-time lover. The sole human woman with whom he was very close.
Because she accepted him. With her aid and care, he found a place for himself in this hostile world. She began the work that I strive to continue.
Ever meet her?
Never had the pleasure, alas. She deserted him a time before he came round to save me. Though he always claimed she'd gone missing.
Subjects aplenty for ballads all around, they said! Lying there for the taking. But I never believed it!
Witcher, whoa there! Come here, be nimble, be quick!
Le Papillon, you lucky scoundrel!
Prrrrr…
Hey, darlin'. Like what you see?
Hey, handsome!
Ha-aw ekh ekh…
Hm… yes?
Hungry? Thirsty?
I married a dopey dullard. Mother said he was, I should have listened…
You lads are all the same!
Somebody, help! Good folk!
Whoa, there, swift swashbuckler!
Greetings. Greetings!
Eeny, meeny, miny, meastie! The witcher killed the big bad beastie!
Thank you for the rescue, witcher!
When fancy's darts fly clear of hearts, folk had best try a little lovage!
It is now thought the very height of la mood to dine on goose livers pickled, then stewed! Hoohoohoo…!
Watch out! I bite! Hahaha!
Madame
Peasant
My dear… you're married, but what difference does it make…? Life's to be lived, for we live but once…
Mhm. Once. So if folk come to consider me a cocotte, it's a label I'll not ever be rid of.
No one will know.. Only I, you and the moon…
That's what they all say. Until a mate buys them a beer, and they brag all about what and how they did with who in which barn!
Ehh… You've not an ounce of romance in you.
Attack! Aaaa-ttaaaaack!
Attack! Aaaa-ttaaaaack!
Thank you, friend - for saving my enchained knightly bum!
Blunder me blind. I would be gone if not for your aid, comrade!
I shall never retreat, not one step!
I shall never retreat, not one step!
Friend…
Enough of that! Behave!
May our dear Duchess Anna Henrietta's spirit rest in peace.
Duchess Anna Henrietta's death has made orphans of us all.
It is right and fitting, witcher, that the duquessa summoned, and you came!
By my troth! It is the witcher who saved us from woe!
By my troth! It is the witcher who saved us from woe!
You let us all down, witcher!
Swish-swash! Swish-swash!
Leaping Lebioda's wounds!
You let us all down, witcher!
Lebioda's weeping wounds!
The lust to do evil… I'll beat it out of you!
Rack-a-thwack! Rack-a-thwack!
The lust to do evil… I'll beat it out of you!
Welcome!
Yes, my Lord?
Courtesan
Drowner
Yaaaawn… Yes?
Do you like it here?
If only I had the coin for a medic…
Those noises, again… I couldn't sleep a wink.
Yaaaaawn…
Ehh, just let me rest.
What is this place?
What is this place? Poor house?
You could call it that. They come here to rest and eat a hot meal.
You help 'em why?
Because they need help.
All right… I can take a hint. Come, time to go.
Are you well, my friend?
Wha… what happened?
Well, I saw your opponents gain the upper hand, so I took the liberty of jumping in. They shan't bother us anymore. We can now have a calm conversation with the proprietor.
I thank you much for your aid… I tried to reason with them, but they'd have beat me blue had you not come along. I'm grateful, immensely.
What'd they want from you?
They are neighbors, wish me to take my folk, the shelter, elsewhere. They dislike that I help the beggars.
I do not oppose going elsewhere were we to have somewhere to go. But you've come with a problem, have you? My turn to aid you.
Need some information.
Need some information. Looking for a man who might've mentioned the bootblack in Rue de Garles.
The bootblack? A feisty lad, I know him…
Any of your… uh, wards supposed to meet him recently or soon?
Forgive me, those I help and I are not so close that I would know. But should you wait, they'll all soon come for their meal.
You can question them yourselves.
All the beggars'll be here?
Sure all your usual beggars'll be here?
They're not obliged to come, of course. But they rarely find a decent meal elsewhere. So almost all in the area eat here.
Thanks, we'll wait.
Thanks. We'll wait. Nice of you to let us.

My dears, I've a matter to address before I serve the soup. These two gentlemen have some questions of you. Pay attention, answer in brief, for if you draw it out your soup will go cold. And we wouldn't want that, would we?
Recently, four of you delivered sealed letters to the bootblack… I know this.
Does anyone know what the gentleman means? Go on, speak up. Romain?
Why should I squeal? We were all told not to mention the letters. We all swore.
You can tell me, Romain. You were given a letter and you delivered it, right? Good work, Romain. Thank you. Who else?
I got one, too. Gave it to the bootblack. And Freshy, he got one. But he can't tell you as he's not here.
I still have mine. I'm to deliver it two days after the Feast of Saint Barnabas.
Letter's meaningless now.
I need the letter. It's very important. It's no use to you anymore.
Let's go. Haven't had a drink in weeks. Besides, doubt that information'd do the duchess any good.
Heh. Why not admit you're simply afraid of her reaction?
She already locked me up once. Can you blame me?
I cannot. At times one must abandon grand politics for a bit of simple pleasure. I believe this is one of those times.
Let's go drink.
Yes, yes and yes. All seem likely. And none are mutually exclusive. But if you'd like to know for certain, you could always ask her yourself.
Think it's a good idea?
Think it's a good idea? After all, we foiled her carefully planned scheme. Think she'll even want to--?
…Talk to you? Would it harm you in any way to try?
Some philosophers think empirical examination the sole path to knowledge.
Actually love to learn her motives.
Praiseworthy, I suppose. Sometimes one should stare evil in the face.
Seems a bit strong. No?
She used my friend as her tool for killing. I believe I've every right to condemn her. But I support your lust for the truth.
Love to learn her motives.
Hoped I wouldn't have to see her again, ever.
What can I say? The road to truth is oft muddy, rutted and largely unpleasant.
Just like the road to Oxenfurt, then.
Thought I was done dealing with Syanna.
I'd like to ask her.
Actually, be happy to do that. To look her in the eyes and ask why she wanted to murder her own sister.
I believe you mentioned the duchess keeps Syanna locked up?
Courtiers were insisting on a harsher punishment, much harsher. Think Anna Henrietta had to protect her sister from a lynch mob as much as she wanted to protect her subjects from a criminal.
One way or another, she's locked away in a secluded wing of the palace, awaiting trial before a court of law. I'd need to get past some guards to see her.
Coming with?
Of course not. I shall await you at Mère-Lachaiselongue. I'll not risk entering the palace after Dettlaff and his minions' rampage.
Besides, I vastly prefer the company of a simple mug of mandrake brew to that of the duchess' vile sister.
So, said straight up it means you're going off to get drunk because you hate Syanna.
I've never been fond of categorical statements of that kind. But I admit I could not vouch for my behavior in her presence.
She treated Dettlaff cruelly, caused his death in the end. And now this…? Atop all that? No, Geralt. I will not go with you. I will await you at the cemetery.
Coming with?
Meet after the ceremony?
So, meet up once it's over? Assuming you'd rather not see Syanna again…
You assume correctly. I shall await you at Mère-Lachaiselongue, with a hot mug of mandrake brew to keep me company.
Ehh, think this might be something Anna Henrietta should now.
As you wish. I shall await you at Mère-Lachaiselongue, a mug of mandrake brew to keep me company.
Not coming with?
No. After the horror Dettlaff brought down upon the city - and in light of Syanna's death - I think it wiser not to appear at the palace.
Probably right. See you later, then.
Before heading to the palace, you might wish to see if Anna Henrietta is not at the city cemetery. She's spent a great deal of time at her sister's grave these last days.
Need to inform Anna Henrietta.
What do we do now?
Now we drink. Unless, that is, you feel a witcherly duty to see the duchess and tell her what we just learned.
What now?
Duchess is safe now, luckily.
Can only guess what drove Syanna. Luckily Anna Henrietta's safe now.
I believe we may dare to assume so. Syanna's death was also the death of the duquessa's only natural rival. She is in no danger, for now.
Pretty rare thing for a ruler.
Yes, yes and yes. All those make sense. And none are mutually exclusive.
Duchess was to be Dettlaff's last victim… Syanna planned it from the start.
Indeed. The logical conclusion, Geralt.
Four seemingly random victims to start, the Virtues their only link. Enough to get folk talking about a righteous, vengeful Beast…
Obscured the victims' links to Syanna. Even as she had those she despised killed off one by one… leaving the duchess for last.
Had she managed to fulfill her plan, none would have questioned the reasons, most would have thought Anna Henrietta had died for her sins.
She was known to show a hard heart on many occasions. Ample proof of a lack of compassion.
Why would Syanna murder her own sister? Out of envy? To take power? From an inborn penchant for evil?
Last victim - the duchess.
Complete the puzzle for you?
Puzzle complete now?
Alas, the matter's ceased to be a tantalizing brainteaser and has turned incredibly grave. We've proof of a plot to assassinate Toussaint's ruler, we've proof of a coup d'état.
Dammit.
What is it? Another name, truly?
See for yourself.
Well, well… I… I must say even I did not expect this…
This time you will see to our duquessa. It seems we underestimated Syanna rather grossly.
Judging by this, Dettlaff was literally supposed to tear her heart out…
Yet first you must snap her neck. Puzzling.
But I was to deliver it personally, let no one else see it. That is what she said. And she was frightening.
You ought to heed folk who are kind and honest. These men helped me a short while ago, helped all of us. If this individual threatened you, you need not keep the promise you made.
All right… Take it. I didn't want to see the bootblack anyways. It's always muddy there…
It's a matter of importance to the duchy. Hand it over. Or I'll take it from you, plain and simple.
Give me that letter.
Stay out of trouble and we'll be dandy.
You're a hero now. A savior! Mhmhmhmh.…
Heheh, you asked for it.
May you shit in your coffin…
Now, be a good lad. Put that back in its scabbard. Go on, I'll wait.
Hey! You! I'm talkin' to you, grayboy!
Mh. That's right.
Bloody hell…
Place mentioned in the note. Archespore saplings are somewhere around here.
Letter proves Count Crespi's behind the sabotage at both vineyards. Gotta tell Matilda and Liam.
Letter suggests a third party's behind the troubles at Liam's and Matilda's vineyards. Still don't know who, though. And I'm no longer likely to find out. Dammit.
Apparently someone's sabotaging operations at Vermentino. But the letter doesn't say who. Hm. Need to keep looking. Could still find out.
Hm, a letter and a key. In a place like this? Oughta be interesting.
Hm. What've we got here? No chance this letter wound up here by accident.
Interesting… This note plus what I found earlier - some third party's causing problems at the vineyards.
Need to find the spot the letter mentions. Bet I'll find something mighty interesting behind whatever door this key opens.
Ducal clerk's looking for help. Could be good coin to be made.
The steward told me you dispatched those belly-aching suppliers handily… Good work.
Thank you. I never thought I'd hear praise from your lips… Usually you find fault in everything I do.
I don't find fault, I am merely honest. As I am now - you did well.
Hmm… Looks like an archespore killed him. Should search the body.
Archespore saplings? Takes a degenerate to cultivate something like this.
Need to incinerate them. Before they spew spores and spread.
Hmm… Looks like an archespore killed him.
Note's clear - someone's out to sabotage Coronata. Shame I don't know who… though I could still find out if I keep looking.
I'm counting on you, witcher.
Please, sir. Do not disturb.
You will help me, won't you?
Come now, madame, monsieur. We shall never get anywhere in this manner…
I care about one thing only - acquiring Belgaard. I will make an infinitely better steward than she will. A pretty face is hardly enough if the head it adorns is empty.
Says the most foppish philanderer of the southern reaches! You'd do better to tend to your vineyard and look less to the grape-stomping lasses.
Please don't bother me. I'm busy.
We shall never forget what you did for us. Our grandchildren will drink your health!
Clear my vineyard, please. It's very important.
I thank you again. And hope the wine's to your liking.
Until you solve all Coronata's problems, I am deep in the cesspool.
Problems Liam de Coronata mentioned - must've been talking about this…
Matilda Vermentino must've meant this when she mentioned troubles…
Well, well. Seems the saboteur came around here, too.
Is it a drink you seek?
Greetings!
Drink, mes amis, eat, drink and make merry! We are no longer in any danger!
Drink, mes amis, eat, drink and make merry! For tomorrow the Beast will devour us all!
Our beloved duquessa…
White-haired witcher… I've seen that dome before, but where?!
Careful, friend!
The Guard! Summon the Guard!
Katakan
Wh-wh-wh-wh-wh-what now?
L-l-l-let me live.
Whoa! A witcher! A serious client, at last! Tell me, what do you need? Honeysuckle? Ginatia petals?
Show me what you've got in stock.
What do you have on offer?
In the mood for a round of gwent?
How about a game of gwent?
Need to get going. Till next time.
Need to get going.
Business all right?
How's business?
The coin is good, but… just between us, I'm going batty with boredom.
I know what my customers want before they open their mouths. Bald men - birch sap. Ladies of all walks - whatever fragrance Duchess Anarietta prefers at the time.
If just once somebody would order some poison… ehh.
Welcome back, master!
Ptooey! Let's ride!
Light the signal fire! Now, cor blimey!
Ngh! Take a pecker to the back!
Why you nimble muffrucker…
Ehh, tittlenicks!
This shan't drag on too long!
Slice! Cut! Kill!
A life for a life.
What the cuttledickens…?
Mug
Witchman!
Oh.
Can you fathom it? Vermentino and Coronata reconciled?
Me oh my! A witchfeller!
Durned-diddly, my gammy leg aches something fierce.
You're back? Here to clear up the mystery of the cow after all?
Don't have time for this now.
Talk some other time, maybe. So long.
We're to miss yet another milestone…? How am I to tell the investor?
Helped you finish the statue like you asked.
Master, what would I have done without you? Countless throngs of Lebioda's followers will praise in prayer.
And you'll pay me, right?

But of course, your reward. The investor is a serious man of enterprise. Our plan foresee mass conversions. With the donations that will follow, we aim to recoup the costs of production in three to five years. Everything has been calculated, you see, down to the last decimal.
Hm, good luck, then. Farewell.
Zoot, we must get back to work soon, immediately, or our plan's worth a dog's runny turd.
So, master, the workers who vanished - how goes the search?
Well? Have you learned how that cow came to fly?
Fine. But that is the sum total - no bonuses or gratuities on top, understood?
That accident - anyone witness it?
Need to know more about this accident. Anyone actually see what happened?
No, but sounds there were. Austerve had just gone to see how Emil was getting along when suddenly we heard an ear-botching boom. Moments later, something smashed into one of the cranes.
Doubt it was the cow that hit the crane.
Probably true. At any rate, come morn we ventured out to see, but the vermin drove us off. With that, all work came to a halt, has remained so since.
Master, tarry no longer, please. Will you take on the matter?
Yes, an unfortunate matter, indeed, to be crushed by a cow… A true shame, Emil - he was a good worker.

I told them at once there had to be a simple explanation. But that lot, no - right away they started in screaming "plague," demanding higher wages for "hardship," "poor working conditions," you see…? They'll ruin me, the blotters.
Mh. My job… is to figure out why a cow fell from the sky? That it?
That, too. The thing is, since none bothered to clear the cow corpse, some filth's overrun the other pit. We fear to venture there.
Necrophages, I know. Already tended to them. Saw the cow and Emil, too, but I need to take a closer look.
Yes, master, that you must. This riddle needs unraveling.
Not surprised. Cow - where'd it come from, what kind was it?
Why, the ordinary spotted kind. Nothing unusual. Its corpse rots in the other pit, sends out its stench. And Emil lies right beneath it. Will you tend to the matter, take on the contract?
What exactly are you doing here?
What exactly's going on here?

Construction of a statue of the Prophet Lebioda. We're carving it. Not all at once, that is, but piece by piece. A pious investor's revived the project after years of neglect. He's engaged all nearby quarries in its completion.
And we would be on schedule were it not for the incident! Please, master… will you look into it?
Fine. I'll look into it. Might be a botched portal, but I doubt it.
Lebioda reward you with progeny aplenty. I shall keep an eye out for your return.
I'll look into it.
They vanished? What's that mean?
Just that, along with ample supplies. I had placed an order. More than a dozen wagons reached the building site, yet five were lost along the way.
Tools, food, building materials and, first and foremost, the specailists we need, the chief architect included.
I wrote to the architect to say the quarry awaits, he should send new plans. But the foreman said the architect was here, at Ardaiso. And this means…
He's missing too. Got it. I'll look around, see what I can learn.
Master, I know not how to thank you. But I beg you to hurry. We shall simply not finish without those five wagons.
Vanished - what's that mean?
Helped you finish the statue.
Beasts shouldn't cause you any more trouble.
Why, that is grand news!
Here, take this. And I thank you, master!
Probably heard the last of the beasts. Burned the nest, eggs, everything.
A praiseworthy precaution, but as I said, I can only pay you what we agreed. I simply haven't any more.
Yeah. You can get back to work. And it wasn't a plague of falling cows.
Did I not say so from the start? A weight off my chest! So what was behind the animal's plummet?
Young slyzard flying over the quarry dropped it. Was trying to get it back to its nest - food for its mother and siblings.
Yeah. Cleared everything up.
My reward - let's talk.
Need to talk about my reward before I decide.
Ahh, time for a good haggle. So, how much would you take?
What? You jest! We mine stone here, not gold!
Hm, you must go lower for it to make any sense to me.
No chance! You shall have what I offer or get out of my sight.
Ah, master, the matter of the statue…? How fare things?
Shaelmaar
One thing - found a handkerchief in the water. Monogrammed "d.l.C." Mean anything to you?
De la Croix?! It cannot be. Was it he the Beast slew?!
Seems so. Knew him well?
Long past. We were close friends, once, but our paths diverged. He was a man of extremes, standing by his companions no matter the odds, fighting his foes to the bitter end.
Foes - he have a lot of them?
He did, but I do not see what that has to do with the Beast. Ah, Geralt, you've struck a raw nerve. Memories of a time long past to which I'd rather not return now.
I understand. We can talk later. Let's go to the tavern.
Found a monogrammed handkerchief.
Someone's watching us.
Seems we've got ourselves an audience.
You think this surprising? The locals will tell the children of children they do not have yet of the day a quartered corpse was pulled from the river.
What now?
This isn't the site of the murder, we know that. Current brought the body here. Corpse got caught in the nets. Guardsmen pulled it out, put it in a boat and took it somewhere.
Need to find out where. I'd like to look at the corpse before it starts to decompose.
The inn - its patrons must have seen the guardsmen, which direction they took. We should ask there.
Guardsmen snipped these nets to untangle the body. Which must've been quartered or chopped up somehow, given how much blood there is.
Body parts were put on a boat, taken somewhere. Need to find out where. I'd like to look at the corpse before it starts to decompose.
The inn - its patrons must have seen the guardsmen, which direction they took. We should ask there.
Look, a boat was launched here. Guardsmen must've loaded the body parts onto it, taken them somewhere.
Need to find out where. I'd like to look at the corpse before it starts to decompose.
The inn - its patrons must have seen the guardsmen, which direction they took. We should ask there.
What now?
We know this isn't the site of the murder. Current brought the body here. Corpse got caught in the nets. Guardsmen pulled it out, put it in a boat and took it somewhere.
I'd like to look at it before it starts to decompose.
The inn - its patrons must have seen the guardsmen, which direction they took. We should ask there.
Snack Vendor
The witcher waited, till the time was true, then twirled, danced and spun - struck the monster right through!
Like a beau who leaves after love's first spurt, so the witcher wooed the shaelmaar, then its foul heart hurt!
Dodge, dive, flee, feint! His razor strikes belly! Shaelmaar's cries ring aloud, blood transforms into jelly!
Our hero's struck deep by the shaelmaar's red claws! Soon the witcher shall perish in cavernous maws!
Woe to us all if the monster's the victor! Then naught shall have come of valor and vigor!
Drink up the ocean and set fire to the wood! For nothing in this struggle can come to any good!
Out, out, brief flame! And thus the witcher's life was snuffed. All our hopes, alas, had turned to dust.
Alas! Poor knightling! The beast heaved its foul girth,
Let loose a roar and knocked him to earth!
Then down came the witcher in one mighty bound, to give fight to the beast, its plans confound!
Alas! Palmerin lies prostrate, he has breathed his last breath!
Avenge him, witcher! Fight bravely, unto death!
For honor! Onward!
Gotta keep it down!
Can only tell where we are when it hears us!
The fate of the beast has been weighed by the gods! Soon the witcher shall triumph, against all odds!
Eh?
Ugh, oh! I think I'm gonna spew.
Sir, what's that your wavin'?
Run! Run! Everbody run!
Ooh, it's the swordsman. Good to see you, here for a spiffing? Dirty boots are a stain on professional dignity, you know! Step on up!
Geralt! I'm pleased you had a change of heart.
The young master and I were just discussing the curious composition of the local soil.
Ooh, it's the chap with the swords. Sir, you look like some beast ate you up, then spat you out. Are you here for a spiffing? Boots make the man, they say! Step on up!
Not wearing boots just now, but guess I could pull a pair on.
Remember what they looked like?
Remember what they looked like?
Of course! I've a mind like a steel trap, as I said. They were ragged, unshaved. Their clothes were tattered. As to their boots, well, I mentioned that already.
Geralt, allow me to ask a question… Listen, lad. I'll be glad to mix another batch of that boot shine for you…
But you must focus now and tell us all you know. Where can we find the beggars?
Well, at the shelter, most like.
Where's that?
Everyone knows. It's just 'round the corner. Up those stairs, then right.
Thanks, kid. For your trouble.
Where'd they get the letters? They pick them up, get them from someone?
I don't know. They'd come, hand me a letter and walk away. I asked no questions.
Where'd the beggars get the letters from?
Beggars… tell us more about them? How many were there?
Why… four. One for each letter.
Just four? Sure you didn't get a fifth?
I can count, you know.
Remember anything else? These beggars have anything in common?
What? Come, now, each was different. Some had mismatched boots, others had no boots at all…
Oh! I know! They all had no home!
Kid, my patience is starting to run a little thin. Now think hard…
Beggars - who were they?
Why didn't you tell us before?
Why didn't you tell us this before, when we first talked?
You didn't ask about beggars, now did you?
Man in the frock coat - you passed him some letters. Remember?
Why, of course. I'm young, got a mind like a steel trap. But…
If you're about to tell me this information'll cost me, forget it.
How'd you get those letters?
Beggars brought them.
Letters you delivered - remember them?
How's business?
How's business?
Well enough, I can't complain. Though it'd be even better were certain folk to sit down for a shine as they stood and chatted.
You've made some nice improvements… I'm rather impressed, both pleasing to the eye and functional.
Isn't it? And it's all thanks to you! The coin you gave me, I invested it all. Thanks again!
You're welcome.
Then I shall take advantage as well. A friend of mine used to say boots should be as clean as the souls that wear them.
Clean boots - clean souls ! A fine slogan!
Guess they could use a spit and polish.
Need to ask you something.
Yet again? Go on, then - I'm a proponent of free speech and will gladly tell you all I know. But why not get your boots shined while we jabber?
Uh-huh?
Argh!
Eee-yaaah!
Now you've a problem.
Chicken?
Armorer
Alms for the poor, sir…?
Oh, bumbotch! They didn't like that!
We should look inside. Remember Joss's words?
Mhm. One bean lies out in the open, guarded by "three nobodies"… Yeah, could be it.
Oh, the three little pigs' homes. You know the story, don't you? "Who's afraid of the big bad wolf…?"
Looks like Big Bad's already blown down the houses of straw and sticks… Brick's the only one left.

Happened like this… A nasty rain caught me while I was out in the woods, so I thought to myself, “I’ll hide in some hollow, for gods’ forbid I get soaked through and catch a cold at my age. So I crawled into a cave. And there inside, something roars at me! Tore out of there so fast, wind had dried my coat by the time I got home.
Velis Stail, herbalist

No one knows exactly when the spriggan called “Grottore” first made its home in the caves at the foot of Mount Gorgon. Spriggans usually prefer isolated backwoods and rarely make dens in caverns.
Yet Grottore seemed to have taken a liking to “grottos,” giving rise to its nickname.
The monster was quite well-known among Beauclair knights, who often talked of it as a potential source of great glory. None were particularly eager to actually engage the monster in combat, however – none, that is, except for the young knight François.

Grottore proved to be a demanding foe. It possessed the ability to teleport, meaning it would appear directly in front of Geralt and mount a surprise attack, dealing strong blows that were impossible to parry. It used primeval magic to control tree roots, which would shoot from the ground on its command, dealing significant damage to any in their way.

It was resistant to the Aard Sign, but vulnerable to burning. Blows from a silver sword would do it harm, despite the bark-like hide covering it like armor.
Grottore
I'd say a wolf, but it has the eyes of a cat!
Wine - the breakfast of champions!
White Wolf! Our salvadore!
A cockerel in your codpiece is worth two in the bush!
A witcher I may not be, but I always find a bottle promptly!
Dammit…
Killer must still be here.
Claw wounds. From five separate claws, spread of a small human hand.
Footprints. Small, bare feet. Lead deeper into the cellar.
Woman from the inn was wearing this coat.
Hurled against the wall with great force.
Used this to batter down the grate…
Took a lot of strength to batter this down.
Killed with a single blow.
Massacred. By a vampire. Not an ekimmara, though. Or a fleder.
Bruxa. Gotta be.
Attacker had no trouble knocking over the cart.
Busted ribs, blood from the ears - took a solid hit…
Throat torn open by man-like jaws.
Man-like except for long fangs.
Need to hurry.
Sounds of a fight. Have to hurry.
In the cellar, gotta be…
River muck. Carried the body in this cart.
Need to hurry.
Black Blood and Moon Dust - could be lifesavers.
Fell down the stairs, broke his neck.
Top quality goods! Only the best!
Good day!
You shan't find anything better in all Toussaint!
I stock the larder of the duquessa herself!
*Sniffs* Dingle a dog! It still stinks in here…
Why you…!
What the feck?!
Ooph! *Sniffs* The stink had better not spread to my wine…
You don't say…!
Yeah, right!
Friend! Looking for the best wine in Toussaint?! It's Geralt of Rivia - remember that name!
Have you heard the tale of Liam and Matilda? Love conquers all, even in business!
All the great poets drank! It's the very reason I cannot be rid of this thirst…
Gaze long enough into an empty goblet, and the goblet's like to gaze back into you!
I wager you could stand to toss back some wine.
Hu-hu-hullo!
You watch where you put those paws!
You'll never guess who won the gwent tourney. The witcher - the very same the duchess summoned from the North!
The Beauclair cemetery's haunted! Haunted, I say! Ghosts prance about, moaning, rattling their chains and dragging the living into graves!
They say all sorts of things about that witcher… Apparently, he's friends with Viscount Julian… the duquessa's former, you know… fellow!
Madman! He's a madman!

While wandering around Toussaint, Geralt did not neglect his vocation and the true core of his existence, namely, pursuing and slaying monsters. Having found a notice on a notice board, posted by a merchant guild beset by some beast, the witcher decided to go to the appointed spot to learn about the details of the matter.

At his destination, Geralt found a ransacked camp. It looked as if it had been destroyed recently. He also happened on the bodies of two merchants. Their wounds had clearly been caused by a monster of ample size.
While combing the surrounding area, the witcher happened on Count Borhis di Salvaress, who claimed the monster Geralt was tracking was a silver basilisk - the last surviving specimen of the subspecies which also happened to be the count's wildly roaming pet, a pet the nobleman desperately wished the witcher would spare.
To make matters worse, it turned out this basilisk was also the quarry of a small company of Crinfrid Reavers.

Geralt decided he would not slay the basilisk.
The count in turn pledged to take more precautions toward safeguarding merchants passing through his pet's feeding range. He also promised that Geralt would acquire ingredients at special prices from herbalists he knew.

Geralt decided that the basilisk had to die. It mattered little that it might have been the last of its subspecies, for fundamentally it remained a dangerous beast. Count di Salvaress was distraught. He threatened that the witcher would never see another reasonable price at the shops of the herbalists he knew.
Geralt decided that the basilisk had to die. He nonetheless refused to hunt it down straight away. By the time he returned, the basilisk had made mincemeat of the four Crinfrid Reavers.

While tracking the basilisk, Geralt found yet another corpse.
As things stood, it seemed a band of Crinfrid Reavers was also hunting the basilisk. They had taken on a contract from a local guild and in their arrogance collected the fee in advance.
Yet the mercenaries somehow took an immediate liking to Geralt, which I find hard to believe, as I am quite familiar with their type…
They offered to join forces with the witcher in fighting the beast and promised to share their reward with him once it was brought down.
Meet the merchants at the camp.
Using your Witcher Senses, investigate the campsite.
Find out more about the second victim.
Use your Witcher Senses to follow the basilisk.
Kill the basilisk with the Reavers' help.
Find the basilisk's lair.
Use your Witcher Senses to follow the sounds.
Mutual of Beauclair's Wild Kingdom
Greetings, greetings…
Lebioda's lesions - nothing but a collection of scars…
Nothing will ever be the same again. Poor, poor duquessa…
First they chug their wine, then they whack each other upside the head.
Someone did a shoddy job stitching up that face…
Have you soup for brains?
Where are your manners?!
You won't believe it! Reginald's statue… it's been crippled!
What? What do you mean?!
His stones… they've been stolen! And the thief's left no clue!
I think I could spot him. I'd just look for a man with a strained codpiece.
Oh my goodness!
Yeees - akh akh - I heard the same.
Akh akh. Rumor has it someone slew Count Salvaress' silver basilisk. When the count learned of it, he blew his lid, dropped dead before nightfall!
Did you hear about the massacre at the last meeting of the historical society?! Devoured, all of them, by some elven - akh akh - statuary!
Godfried Nork - akh akh - the famed charcutier… imprisoned! For poisoning Her Grace's court with rotten sausages!
Witcher Geralt! Akh akh… In the flesh!
My regards.
Geralt! Akheh… Toussaint's savior extraordinaire!
The tourney may know only one… akh! Champion! Akh!
And the brave knights - akh - lunged - akh akh - at one another's throats… akh.
Maybe I should mull a bit of wine? To soothe the throat…
Spare a poor, innocent bard…
Watch out! Akh akh!
Black is the color of my true love's hair…
His face so soft and wondrous fair…
You slimy splotch of bull barf…
Welcome, Sir Ravix, Toussaint's best sword-swinger!
Craft something for me? Look, got this diagram…
Craft something for me, would you?
Know you're busy, but you up for a round of gwent?
Care for a round or two of gwent?
So long.
So long.
Show me what you got there.
Let's see what you got in stock.
Armor chromed, engraved or fluted! Whatever your heart's desire!
You are Sir Geralt of Rivia, Bridge your crest? The tourney's victor? This is a great honor!
Giant Centipede
Wait!
Why?
The stalk will sprout abruptly. Very abruptly. We must be careful.
All right! Toss them!
Agh… Something's always gotta go wr--
The home stretch.
Incredible…
Admire the view later. First we must deal with…
…him.
Now, we must plant them by the path near Longlocks' tower… Then prepare to meet the giant.
Right, this is the spot. Pull out the beans.
This will be a good spot to plant the beans - once we have them all.
While snooping about the cursed Trastamara Estate, Geralt happened on a strange, spoon-like key. Attached to it was a note.
The note labeled the strange spoon as the property of the Pheasantry, known far and wide to be the finest tavern in all the duchy of Toussaint.

The witcher decided to follow the lead and headed to the Pheasantry to see what he could find. Though the innkeep denied ever having seen the peculiar utensil, she did suggest that Geralt search the tavern's cellar. For it was there that the previous owner's documents were stowed.

In the cellar Geralt found some notes. These in turn stated the spoon was a key to the studio of a legendary elven cook. The studio supposedly lay hidden amidst the ruins of a temple to the goddess Danamebi in the Blessure Forest…
Geralt reached the temple ruins, descended into the cellar, and found the long-forgotten studio-kitchen of one Ra'mses Gor-Thon, where treasure was as plentiful as dust and cobwebs!
Read the note attached to the spoon.
Ask the owner of the Pheasantry about the mysterious spoon.
Search the Pheasantry's cellars.
Read the notes found in the Pheasantry.
Find Gor-Thon's studio and look for treasure.
Spoontaneous Profits!
Here in Beauclair, all's right and fair!
Have your chit-chat with someone else.
Begone from my sight.
The duquessa's champion… Ptooey.
Were I in your boots, I'd go far away. Your protectress is no longer around.
We've got to go at him together! Together!
I'll tear your legs from your bum!
Mutant!
Damned. wandering gray-haired pee-pee-licker!
For Duchess Henrietta!
Noooo!
Think you can do whatever you please?!
Understood!
Sheathe that blade, you twit!
Watch out! He's a witcher!
I knew you for a scallywag from the start!
That's better.
Yes, kind sir?
Greetings, sonny.
Oh, if I was young...
You're twisted!
Dog
Need something crafted. Could you do that?
Could you craft something for me?
Straggen - name's familiar. Ran into him a while back.
What's this?! He must have been a horrible houndshagger. Decent folk don't bear that name.
Can't say if that's true for all the Straggens, but this one sure wasn't decent. Met a bad end, too. Justly so.
You carved up the knobcupper! I knew it!
Druids did it for me, actually. Burned him alive.
Oh, lovely, lovely!
Guy named Straggen - ran across him already.
Mind taking a glance at these diagrams?
For you, witcher, I will take two!
I regret to say only a grandmaster could decipher these scribblings. And a grandmaster I am not…
Found some interesting diagrams…
See you later.
Farewell.
Show me what you've got on offer.
Show me what you have on offer, will you?
Ha, the witcher we love to love! I hope you've gutted some particularly nasty nastiness since last we met… Ah, what am I saying - of course you have.
Well, well… Starling Straggen of house Bum-Diddled Harlotsbrood has bit the dust. May he rest in pain and agony!
You've earned yourself a steep price cut here, witcher.
Witcher! A moment of your time, may I?
Busy! Busy, busy, busy!
I've no time.
Did you find your cell comfortable, wangler?
A witcher. Hrmph. Whatever…
A witcher, pfff. They're smearing his hiney with honey. I don't know why…
Ahoy - hiccup!
Hiccup! Ehh…
Rump-riding rosé! Hiccup! It always gives me - hic! - trouble!
Diddle a dog… hic! These hiccups…
To bury the murderous lass in in one crypt with the duchess - it's not decent!
Murderer or no, she was the duchess' sister, shared her blood. She should lie with her kin.
Hare
Bugger off, troublemaker.
Master witcher, yer coin.
Shan't call the Guard, but do us a wee favor and never come back. Can do without patrons like you.
Barghest
Count Monnier
Sir Milton de Peyrac-Peyran murdered… A knight so honorable, so esteemed…
Witchers, do they, uhh, have need of squires?
Master witcher, you wouldn't be seeking an apprentice, would you?
At your service, master.
Master?
Little Flint Girl
Hey, look. Who'sss that? Thass's that… White Waffle. The Whizzer. Gerant. They say he… you know, slapped them all down - Stills, Colossus and Mancomb.
Hey! Well parried, that! And the riposte - yes!
And I tell you, the Maestro'll always be top dog! Why, since old Raymond started pushing up daisies, no one's even challenged him!
And no one ever will!
When I chop, you'll be bumbopped!
You either drink with us, or you're against us!
What is he doing here…? Help!
Too too too too mmm-hmm mmmhmm…
{N'ees behéfth ne bhampair ne sas mallaich! Esse deireadh tadhail an-seo.} [Curses, vampires - I did not sign up for any of this! This is my last time here.]
{An tus Bèist, thaë a’anval bhampair… Sluagh-diccette a Toussaint ealdor fion y altaich!} [First the Beast, then the vampire attack… And they said Toussaint would be but wine and respite!]
Tah rah ree-tah rah rah…
{Garean!} [Watch out!]
Tah ree rah… {Que?} [What?]
Cheerio!
Hm?
Hm!
Yaaaaawn…
Regretfully, sign-ups are now closed. So sorry.
They always did seem to have a fondness for one another.
Hm… now which one will serve best?
Uhh, do all contain the same hints? Err…
Please collect your adventurer's kit - basket, letter, telescope and lantern.
Geralt! You're here!
Come on, let me have a look.
Do you see anything? They should be in the woods.
Gustav and Consuela… My, my… who would've thought?
Let me!
Harlotsbrood!
Oh, yes! I heard the same, myself!
Impossible!
May fortune smile upon young Liam and Matilda.
Coronata, ptooey! Hound's hinies, the lot!
The duchess died! For your sins!
Why are you still here?! You mean to foul up more things?!
Do what they summoned you to do, then pack up and go back where you came from.
A high and mighty Northerner, dog diddled dunglicker…
Everyone! Murderers!
I heard it was the witcher who sent all those vampires against the city. So he could play hero!
The witcher and our duchess' sister? Partners in crime - he even helped her do in our dearest duquessa…
More weeping and wailing's been heard near Caroberta Woods. No doubt it's the spirits frolicking 'midst the ruins of Termes palace.
You cat-licked doo-doo diddler.
Hullo.
Oh, you scamp! You beat me. It's not happened in years! Your fists, they're… glorious.
Thanks.
I'm gob smacked, I am, I've to drink it off. Ooff! Good fight! To speak true, I'm pleased you stripped me of the title. I shall have more time to pursue my chief interest, now.
Witcher Geralt of Rivia is hereby crowned Fisticuffs Champion of Beauclair! Bravo!
Behold, your trophy.
A life without liquor's like loving without licking.
You fought well. Not near as well as I did, of course. My advice? Drink. Then drink more. Inadequate intoxication - that is clearly your problem.
Mhm. We'll see next time.
One thing I've learned - a man thumps like he drinks!
To their bosoms your gods hold you.
Folk of interest to meet on the road is an honor.
A beautiful day for a tourney!
Hail, fellow, well met!
Toussaint! Anna Henrietta!
For honor! And art! And poetry!
To arms! To arms!
Life's like an infant - it must be borne.
Bathing tears away at the skin, and thus brings death closer!
Fortune feeds on the poor.
Ehh, brother?
Dammit! Gotta catch it.
[Attack the monster.]
Let's eat, using the spoons.
This isn't right… I miss something?
Listen, gonna stand up real slow. Gotta search the house again. Sit tight. I'll be right back.
Calm down.
Been searching for the right spoon for years, right? But curses can be tricky.
Key to this one just might be that you can't eat with your own spoon.
That's why we've swapped.
Let's swap spoons.
We can't use spoons.
No, that won't work. You've been looking for a spoon that would feed you, but there's no such spoon. We need to eat without spoons.
Open your eyes. You need to see your likeness.
Let's eat, not using the spoons.
The curse - exact wording…
Need to get this right. Words of the curse were: "None shall sit and dine with you at your table, no spoon you have shall sate you, never again shall you wish to spy your reflection in the mirror."
I'm not gonna hurt you. Wanna help.
I've seen the words of the curse on the walls. Think I know how to lift it.
You tried to bring folk here, convince them to sit at the table with you, right? Well, I'm gonna be your guest now. Your willing guest.
Just need a bit for Regis.
And now we'll tend to you.
[Try to lift the curse.]
Seems I'll have to kill the wight in its own junk heap.
Dammit… didn't work. Ate that vile stuff for nothing.
Got the brew for Regis, at least. Can't do anything for the wight, though. Except cut it down.
Hope there's a drop of brew left in the cauldron for Regis.
Think it worked… Just, not quite like I expected.
Need to see what happened to the wight.
Won't be hard to find, given its stench.
Cook hasn't had time to make the brew… Just foul, muddy water now.
Now to carve out its salivary glands…
Wight's salivary glands'll have to do for Regis. High time I got them to him.
Shit, screwed up with the curse. Regis'll get what he wants, though. There is that.
Cloud Giant
Geralt decided to go home to Corvo Bianco.
At his new abode, an unexpected guest awaited… Yet it was someone Geralt was more than glad to see.
Go home.
Be It Ever So Humble…
Know what they're slopping up for supper tonight?
I've no clue. But we're better off chomping grass the way that canteen reeks.
The bleeding bumwipes! And to think they locked me up for selling rancid food.
Nors, what you were selling had no right to be called food. That was worse than rat poison.
Rubbish! Well-aged meat, that's all it was!
Hah! Your aged meat had half of Toussaint galloping to the privy!
That's because our courtiers have the bellies of colicky newborns.
Should have sold your slop to peasants, then.
Are you daft? First, peasants make their own food, and second, nobles pay a spit load more.
Claw marks… Sharp, hooked claws. Monster had an easy time climbing on the roof…
Smashed against the wall… skull cracked. Died immediately.
Head, shoulder and neck wounds… Monster attacked from above. Jumped off the roof, I bet.
Throat ripped open… larynx crushed…
Stomach wall cut open in three places. Damaged organs, arteries.
Sliced aorta. Fang marks alongside… but they're old, scarred over.
Gunk… Is that venom? Hmm. Narrows the list of suspects.
Beast killed the children, but didn't eat them… Something scare it off? Or grab its attention?
Snff snff. Smell's not blood. Need to investigate.
Blood stains… dried.
Paw prints. Bipedal beast. Walks hunched over.
