Such jests are not appreciated!
When I think of those Coronata swindlers, I can barely choke back the bile!
You're a witcher, right? Help us, you must! Monsters in the field ahead!
Lebioda's wounds! Witcher! Monsters, there!

It looked gold to me!

So long.

The best armor around! That is what I forge! Ah, so sorry.

That peasant broke the rules.
Who ever let him in?

What're you gonna do about it?
Mh. Well, couldn't really give a crap.
You boor, you churl!
I will not stand for this! Just you wait, I'll teach you some manners…

Outside! Now!

That witcher from the North - he's here for good! The duchess gave him a vineyard for his service to the duchy!

Truly? I find that hard to believe…

Geralt of Rivia, our hero!
Ow, that hurts! What is it?
Lebioda shower you with warmth!

Hehehehe… O captain, my captain!

With round one completed, the standings are as follows. Agnetha Skold and Eric van Vrog - both disqualified. Geralt of Rivia has defeated Hamal ogn Dangbahli of Ofier. In the semifinal, Geralt shall face the defending champion, Ambassador von Hinn!

With round one completed, the standings are as follows. Geralt of Rivia - eliminated. Agnetha Skold and Eric von Vrog - both disqualified. Consequently, His Excellency the Ambassador of Nilfgaard shall now face Hamal ogn Dangbahli.
As gwent is a gentleman's sport, we expect all its players to demonstrate impeccable manners, and we cannot tolerate any disturbances.
Thus, by decision of Count Monnier, the contestants from Novigrad and Skellige are hereby disqualified.
Gentleman's sport - bah! Well, I'm a lady. And we ladies don't give a flyin' fart about a tourney where any measly prick can accuse us of cheatin'!
I'd never have lost if you hadn't cheated!
In my land, folk who slander like that don't live long! 'Cause we don't let 'em!
Accuse me of cheatin' again, and I'll cut yer tongue out.
Enough! Hands to yourselves!
Good match. Thanks.
And upon your victory, congratulate I you. What drove me to wager a sword against you, know I not. Clearly to guide me the Universe ceased.
Here, you may it serve well.
Far be it from me to criticize your modus operandi, but… the searching, it took quite some time. Ah, I suppose we shall have to wait for the right light once we arrive.
Painting this masterpiece gonna take long?
A mere six hours. The sun won't allow us to work any longer than that. Oh, but the time will fly by! We'll chat, swap tales…
Better yet, lemme down a potion. Time'll definitely fly by in a state of lethargy. And no need to swap tales.
No, no, no! Your expression, your posture - they must be just so! You must look alive, with fire in your gaze! Lethargy is out of the question!
Come on, give it some thought. You could title the painting "A Witcher Lying Senselessly on the Heath."
You jest. Haha. A jesting witcher.
We have had fantastic luck with the weather. The light is perfect, absolutely perfect!
A feather… broken. There was a fight.
You mean to cross the barbarous Barbarossa? Not on your life!
But why keep her in a cage? Eggs from free range birds are so much better. Ah well. Where's the key?
Outdated. Already freed the goose.
Hmm. Doesn't seem to be at home.
Perhaps she left some tracks behind? Go on, use those kitty-cat eyes.
Goose feathers… must've been flapping its wings. Or did it just get plucked?
Honk honk honk honk!
Legs? In ruby red slippers?
From a tale about a wizard from Ofier. You might not know it.
Contract from a goose. That's new.
Do you really aim to concern yourself with that?
A true witcher should never abandon poultry in distress.
Honk honk honk honk!
You're welcome.
Honk honk honk honk!
Would've preferred a magic bean, but not about to complain.
Look! She laid a golden egg for you! Haha!
Heh. If only all my employers were that generous…
Good thing you posted that notice. Never would've found you, otherwise.
Honk honk honk honk!
Hey, there, in the trees! Some kind of camp?
Here it is. Got it.
Defend the goose! The golden eggs will be ours!
The goose is ours! Her golden eggs as well!

One moment.

Just a minute.

Penny for your thoughts. Lemme guess - succubus twins?

Even an old necrophage corpse?

Well, what's new?
A thousand thunderin' sea devils!

Hahahahaha!

I doubt it, myself. But the wife, she went berry-picking once. Came back to say she'd seen walls 'midst the trees.
And? Did she not go back to rummage? See if there was treasure to be had?
No. I told her - there might be treasure, there might not be. Monsters, though, there'd be for certain. Best not venture close.
Will you stay with us, witcher? Now that you've a vineyard?
Hey! Geralt! All the best!
That witcher's rather handsome.
The duchess summoned him… I wonder what for.
The noises at the cemetery… it's thieves ripping caskets from the ground, I'm sure. You only hear them at night, because they're scared of the Guard!
You hear? The Ardaiso quarry's cursed. Cows fall upon it from the sky!
The blacksmith's wife, she's always showing off their costlies. Yet I hear they bought it all with loans from Cianfanelli…
Are you mad?!
Hey there!
Hullo!
Lebioda's wounds…
Who the devil knows? Perhaps it's true.
Hey! You gray-haired chit!
Hullo!
Hmmm… Hm hm.
Ah! Oh, help!
Someone willing to pay me for resolving the problem?
Not a soul. Strange.

Here lies Pablo Diego José Francisco de Paula Juan Nepomuceno María… - yeah, that's not it.
Hmm, noises started right around then.
Louis de Corentin - "…died on the day of Saint Zoatham's Remembrance."
All right. Gotta move one of them out.
Louis de Corentin. Raise your sighs to the Prophet Lebioda on his behalf.
Pretty fresh. Funeral wasn't too long ago.
Here lies Margot de Corentin.
Smashed. As if someone threw it against the wall.
Hmm. Gold. Can't be grave robbers. None worth their salt would've left this.
Sir Conan of Braye End. Died of over titillation while witnessing an act of unicornipositusphilia. Interesting - but not what I'm looking for.
Noise is clearly coming from that tomb. Impossible.
Hm, something's not right. Need to hide, see how things play out…
Right, dark now. Where could I hide…?
Behind this statue, maybe…?
I agree completely, young man - loess is clearly more adhesive than loam.
Isn't that the truth! I noticed it myself. But clay, now that's a real pickle to clean off!
Greetings.
He's a horny one!
I didn't do anything!
And verily I say unto you, if men were but to let the Prophet Lebioda's teachings into their hearts, this world would be a more pleasing place.
Thus raise your voices with mine - O Prophet Lebioda!
O Prophet Lebioda…
O Prophet Lebioda…
I swear to live according to thy teachings.
I swear to live according to thy teachings.
And never to stray from the straight and narrow path which thou hast wrought for us.
And never to stray from the straight and narrow path which thou hast wrought for us.
Agh, dammit. Sure you left them here?
Yes, right there! I'd prepared everything. Set it out, ordered and organized.
Hmm, might've toppled downhill or something. Fine, I'll take a look around.
Fine. I'll look around.
Ugh. Really don't feel like it. You asked me to pose, not… investigate. Sorry, but I refuse to go looking for your paints.
Do you mean that? Witcher, don't do this to me. I don't deserve this, it's-- it's not my fault. They were here, I swear, they--
Next time, make sure you're prepared before you bother a witcher about something like this.
Waste of time. Not about to go looking.
Can't you use different paints?
Wouldn't happen to have another set with you?
And, uh, nothing you could use instead?
My word! Would you really have me scrawl with charcoal like an animal?
Ladies, gentlemen, my lieges… Forgive me for being forward… but have you perchance seen a set of paints and brushes nearby?
Eugenie… I believe this peasant wants something from us.
My paints, my brushes… I had prepared them, they-they were here.
We've not seen any journeyman's tools, my good man. Of that I assure you.
There a problem?
Yes! An immense one! I cannot possibly paint without my… paints! I'm done for! Unless… you would be kind enough to locate them?
I heard some Nordling drove off the Beast. This was you, yes?
Strange land, yes, Nordling? One that cuts down its own heroes…
{Esse liuet fear aep caer…} [So far from home…]
{Ech, Toussentien esse liuet ferranch…} [Ehh, these Toussaintlies really rile me…]
{Quess'aen a va?!} [What are you doing?!]
You! Watch it!
How go things, Nordling?
{Que?} [What?]
Your Grace… this might not be the best idea.
I've made my decision. Prepare to depart.
Geralt of Rivia, master witcher.
I was not mistaken. You arrived and trouble followed soon after.
Step aside. Got a matter for the duchess.
At last, witcher. We've been on tenterhooks! Did you catch Milton's killer?
Case is more serious than we thought. The Beast - I couldn't kill it, didn't manage.
Case just got more complicated.
Found the Beast. But that's it.
Found the "Beast of Beauclair." Just couldn't kill it.
We send you after a monster, and you return with nothing? We are very disappointed.
Situation's not quite that simple. Beast's a powerful vampire.

Pfff, is this a problem? Is it too much for a witcher? A monster slayer?  But everyone knows how to end a vampire. Draw him by trick into sunlight. Or arm yourself with ample garlic and drive a stake through its heart.
Garlic's useless against vampires. Sun and stakes don't hurt 'em, either. Those methods - pure invention, only work in legends and fables.
And buckthorn? When I was a child, grandmama Ademarta always claimed buckthorn drives off vampires.
Silver sword's your best option for keeping them at bay. But it won't get the job done - 'cause only a higher vampire can truly kill another of its kind.
Excuses… Your Grace, I shall assemble a battue, bring the matter to its end at once. The witcher need but tell us where to find this monster.
Go ahead, send them to their death. Certain death.
To a lone witcher, perhaps. To forty of my men at arms, but another skirmish.
Go ahead. Let 'em go to their deaths.
Stay out of this.
Whoa, this is work for a witcher, not for your guardsmen.
Yet when a witcher fails, my guardsmen must step in. I'll take my best - forty hardened veterans. No vampire can stand up to that.
Forty, fifty, a hundred - doesn't matter. Won't make any difference against him.
You have not seen my guardsmen in action.
Can they fight fog? Hit a target that moves faster than the wind?
How… what creature can do such things?
Creatures like this one. Higher vampires, we call them. Each one's a little different… unique or exceptional, you might say.
Some transform into giant bats, others communicate with animals, command them.
Yet all are still brainless beasts.

Dead wrong. Thinking of lesser vampires - alps, ekimmaras, katakans, for instance. They're ruled by instinct, sure. Attack anything that smells of blood. Higher vampires? They think. They employ reason.
Monsters driven by reason… A curious contention. What, then, do you intend to do?
We all await. You are holding things up. May we depart for Castel Ravello?
Yeah, ready to go.
Excellent. Give me a moment - I must don something more appropriate and concealing. Then we will be off.
Let's go.
Need more time.
Make haste! Time is of the essence…
Need some time.
Your Grace, what you propose is far too dangerous. The witcher should go alone…
It pleases me to see you gentlemen finally agree on something, but I've made my decision.
We shall go, accompanied by the best possible escorts - you, captain, and Geralt.
We will travel incognito. We've no wish to give the court any reason to gossip…
For the duration of this mission I release you from your obligation to adhere to court protocol. In short, from now on I am Anna Henrietta, not Your Grace.
Yes, Your Grace! Errr. Witcher, are you ready?
Wait… Your Grace wants to go with me? Out of the question.
I hope you do not suppose we will sit on our ducal hiney and do nothing while our duchy is in grave danger?
What do you mean, "we"?
This specific wine - tell me more.
Sangreal - never heard of it.
It's highly unlikely you've ever had a chance to partake of it. As I said, it is only ever served to the ducal family.
Didn't stop it from ending up on that scrap of paper… unless, Your Grace's sommelier is mistaken.
In matters of wine, Benoit is never mistaken. If he says it's Sangreal, it is Sangreal.
We must ride to Castel Ravello at once, discover what has happened.
Hmm… I admit to being swayed, witcher. You may be right… Do you know anything about the blackmailer?
Got one lead - a few scraps of paper. Blackmailer wrote the names of the vampire's victims on them.
One of them's stained - a drop of wine, looks like… So damn little to go on.
You've no idea how wrong you are, my dear. Send for the ducal sommelier! Hop, hop!
In Toussaint, wine is sacred. Here there is no such thing as "a drop of wine" or stains therefrom. They are stains from a drop of Est Est, Erveluce, Fiorano…
Your Grace wished to see me?
Witcher, show him the paper scrap.
Benoit, can you determine which wine made this stain?
Mhm… mm, yes, yes… The west bank of the Sansretour, that's rather obvious. Aged in barrels of Beauclair oak… Hue - deep burgundy, clarity - high…
It's simple. Sangreal. The 1269 vintage.
That's… That's impossible. The wine is produced at Castel Ravello. Especially and exclusively for the ducal table…
Perhaps some Sangreal was stolen? We must go to the vineyard, see if there's not been an incident.
I'll find the blackmailer, free the vampire's lover.
You were to destroy him, not help him.
No one else should die - that's most important. Soon as the woman's safe, he'll have no more reason to kill.
Free the vampire's lover.
An innocent woman's been abducted.
Which is why that's my aim now - to prevent further attacks.
Vampire's only half the problem. Blackmailer's at fault, chiefly. Kidnapped the woman to control the vampire.
And what do you propose to do?
Try to talk to him - that's our best bet.
I cannot believe this… Her Grace summons a witcher to kill a monster. Instead, he wishes to chat with it!
Know what I'm doing. His lover was kidnapped. He's being blackmailed.
Blackmailed? Be so kind as to explain how a vampire might be blackmailed.
Higher vampires, they're like us - motivated by emotions, not instinct. Not only are they intelligent to an extreme, they're emotionally… rich, capable of feeling many things. Even love.
This one fell in love with a woman, a human. And he'll do anything to keep her from harm.
You do not, I trust, suggest we let Milton's killer go free? Or wait until it murders again? We must render it harmless as quickly as possible.
Wanna find him, try to talk to him.
This is no common "monster."
It's way beyond being some "monster." This is a powerful being that's walked the world for centuries.
Impossible. If so great is their power, why have they not killed or enslaved us all?
Don't usually meddle in our matters. Mostly stay out of our way 'cause they don't care about humans one way or the other.
And they do not fear we shall wipe them out one day?
Huh. They'd probably be pretty amused if you asked them that. They're well aware of their strength.
Then what can we do? Do you have a plan?
Your Grace, I have doubled the guard. The palace is secure.
Mhm… And what of the funeral preparations?
As Your Grace wished, the deceased will be buried with the highest honors.
And our dearly departed Milton de Peyrac-Peyran shall posthumously receive the Order of Ademarta…
Yes? Have you any needs?
My Lord?
Heeheehee!
Achoo!
It's all up to Vivienne.
Doesn't matter what we agreed. It's Vivienne's decision. She can either try it or not.
Of course. But I could not live in the knowledge it was I who brought an ill fate down upon her.
Should try the water method.
Method using a pool of water's better. Poses no threat to Vivienne.
Naturally! You must know you can count on me. I shall bear it all. But Vivienne… I fear she might be too proud to agree to such a thing.
I'll meet her after the last contest. Talk to her. She could agree.
Sorry. Promised her I wouldn't tell.
Vivienne gave me the details of her situation, but she did so in confidence. Promised I wouldn't tell anyone.
But I am not just anyone! Why, I would do anything for her! I was the one to ask you to help her. You cannot shut me out now.
I'm sorry. Look, in time, Vivienne'll come to understand what she owes you, I'm sure of it. But until then, you gotta understand the whole world doesn't revolve around you.
How dare you lecture me! This is not the aid I sought! And to think I gave up my spot in the tourney to you! I regret it, now. Do you even intend to compete to the end?
Or now that you've bound Vivienne to your terms, you no longer see the need?
I don't back out of anything. I'll take part in the last skirmish. Besides, Vivienne'll be busy till the tourney's end.
Indeed. In that case, you must meet the other knights of your team. They await near the arena's entrance, by the training ground.
Got it. Thanks.
Wanna finish the tourney.
Tourney doesn't interest me anymore. I'll wait in the tent until Vivienne's done with all her duties.
As you will.
Backing out of the tourney. Gonna wait for Vivienne's decision.
I'm counting on you, witcher. And I'm content we finally know something. What now? We know all, so you need not see the tourney through. You could withdraw.
True, I shall get an earful from the herald should you fail to show for the last contest… but it's nothing I can't handle. So, what will it be?
Best route? Ritual with the oriole egg. Surest method, won't put any third parties at risk.
Third parties? I am no third party!
Hmm… Lemme talk to her. Could very well appreciate your eagerness, change her mind. But it'll have to be her decision.
Need to perform the egg ritual.
Which method do you believe to be best for Vivienne?
Don't know yet.
But you've some notion, have you not? Do not tell me you seriously consider drastically shortening her life when I stand prepared to shoulder the burden!
You mean… become a bird themselves…?
Theoretically. See, curse grows weaker once it's transferred. Might end up as just an appetite for seeds and worms. All outcomes are on the table, though. Death included.
I am prepared to sacrifice, give my life for her. Just as King Vridank's knight did for the beautiful Queen Cerro!
Knew that already. But are you prepared to swallow bugs for the rest of your life?
… Yes.
Heard of one other method that could work. Curse could be lifted via her reflection, say, in a pool of water.
Thing is, we'd need someone who'd willingly assume the burden of the curse, take it on in her stead.
Tough case. Curse's hold on her grows stronger every day. And I'm a witcher, not a miracle worker.
Spell's complicated.
We were both right, actually. It is a curse. One that's transforming Vivienne into a bird. Her condition's getting worse.
Gods! A curse that is a worse affliction than disease… What now?! Can you help her?
That'll depend on her. I'll try, if she asks me. Significant risks involved, though - shortening her life to about another seven years included.
What?! This is not what we agreed!
A powerful curse afflicts her.
Did you learn anything?
Yeah.
Then speak, man! Can you not see I am out of my mind with worry?! What ails her?!
She asked me not to talk about it.
But I want only the best for her! Perhaps I shall be able to help or… I don't know, console her, at the least.
Blue bridge on a black field, three red diamonds on a white one.
Woman riding a bear, yellow field.
Need to find my tent. Should look around for the one with my crest.
Fire Swallower
It's time I stepped out into the world and wandered. The duquessa's death marks the end here.
Witcher, why did you not take the blow for the duquessa?
Should I break one of my rules once, I am bound to break many more.
A knight is one who does not what he wishes, but what he should do.
You fight well, yet still, you shall perish!
Defend yourself!
Taste my cold steel!
Good deeds are always rewarded.
Peace and prosperity.
That's enough!

The young bootblack whose name Geralt never learned was an extremely charming scamp, in that cheeky, lovable rascal, street urchin sort of way. He also demonstrated striking entrepreneurial flair, so much so, in fact, that it got him into trouble at times. Geralt saved him from one such scrape by fending off a group of men intent on giving him a thorough tanning. The bootblack had done his share to deserve this, having spilled his wastewater in front of their shop every day in an attempt to muddy more boots and drive more customers his way.

Geralt took such a liking to this enterprising little shoeshine boy he decided to invest some coin in his business. He did not have to wait long to see the effects of this investment. The bootblack used these funds to improve his stall and purchase additional equipment. Business was booming!

Geralt’s path crossed that of the bootblack again later on. Once more, the reason had something to do with Dettlaff. The lad was able to tell Geralt and Regis how the letters with the Beast’s victims’ names on them had been delivered to Dettlaff. It can be truly amazing how much useful information one simple child laborer can possess.
Bootblack
Oh boy, oh boy!
Show me your sword?
Hahahahaha!
Gueule
Slyzards
All right, all right, already… You helped us. Thanks bunches. Happy?
Welcome.
Nice day.
Simpleton!
Don't kill me! I'll pay!
Exhibition Curator
Silly Bear
Giving you one last chance - yield.
The damned harlot got us into this… Kill him! Attack!
Wasn't expecting to see you two here.
We thought you could use our help, so--
Witcher. This is no time to explain. Where is Rhena?
Expect to answer a lot of questions inside.
Let us go, then.
Matthieu Lessoc
Juggler
Hm?
Me strength's gone.
Miserable. And hungry.
Make like a ball of yarn and unravel!
They say that witcher drove the vandaguild from Mont Crane! He killed Filibert Fourfingers, too, though before the bully croaked - chop! He made him Filibert Nofingers!
Now Her Gracious Highness has ordered all the hills planted with garlic instead of vines. And every house in town must hang at least three bushels from its windows. To scare off the blood guzzlers!
In my day, were those ever tourneys…! Once a knight's horse croaked on him. But he didn't back out, no, sir! He hired an ass from a peasant and, I kid you not, rode that ass to victory!
But that is complete and utter claptrap!
Bah! The nonsense that comes out of your mouth…
Honestly? It's a shame you killed the Beast. Now we shall abandon all morality whatsoever!
Sure, go on, drink up while you're young, coin in hand…
Who would've thought? Knights trading in wine, while some witcher guards the common folk…
Do you think the duquessa's death will change anything? Hardly!
Aaah, the whole place is rubbed, botched and wanked…
Your health - may you keep it ever more!
Crikey! Help!
He should've never taken this risk. Must've really wanted the armor.
Looks like he came here to hunt the shaelmaar I slew.
Cept he failed to make it home.
Whatever beast the witcher was hunting, doesn't seem like he killed it.
Gotta keep my eyes peeled.
Left his school's symbol on the wall. Clever. Gotta keep a look out for more.
More symbols… Where you gonna lead me?
Collapsed building. Foundations probably caved in. Literally undermined.
Cave entrance… Let's see if this witcher left any tracks.
Must be the corpse of the witcher from the School of the Bear.
I can probably make really good use of these diagrams.
Remaining diagrams at the vineyard? Maybe I can find them.
Aye, and pigs can fly!
Fire be praised!
Aaa, what?
Good sir?
Oooy!
Please! Spare me!
Heeeeelp!
Wanna fight.
The rules governing the Beauclair fist fighting circuit - are you familiar with them?
Hmm, you fight… with fists… There much to add beyond that…?
You must make a wager to join the contest. There are three champions. Challenge them all, defeat them honorably, and you may try your luck against the Maestro.
Your mama…
Guess you'd know - since your mom's a bitch.
Ugh, pathetic. This'll be easy. What's wrong? Afraid? Gut feeling queasy?
Think you're confused - that sounds a lot like your sister.
Think you're confused, that sounds more like your sister. I'm immune to disease, but even I'd die if I kissed her.
You aren't worthy to empty my sister's bedpan! You mange-ridden mutant! Not even a man!
You're annoying.
Now I know how you do it. Just annoy your opponents to death.
Put up your guard!
Finally…
Let's end this pitiful farce. You, witcher, are the dullest man alive.
Done with this. You're weak - just trying to avoid a fight.
You're weak.
Let's fight, already.
Rather fight than chat.
Fancy insults - not my thing. Know other more effective means.
Bored of talking. Time to fight.
Bored of talking. Time to fight.
Let's fight, already.
You're just too dumb to get insults this brutal.
See why'd you say that, you dim flapdoodle. Too dumb to grasp insults this brutal.
Ehh, I've got to admit - you know how to roast a man. You win.
Mean we're not gonna fight?
Why? I told you, you've won.
Should've quit before we began - gonna make you wish you'd turned tail and ran.
Why, you… bad, uh…
Should've quit before we even began.
Your bones look thin, your breathing's wheezy.
Afraid one punch might kill you - it's got me uneasy.
Afraid I might kill you - it's got me uneasy.
Yeah. Because you stink.
Yeah. You stink something vicious. It's making me sick.
Pfff… Give it up, go home, your efforts are futile. Your wit's as flaccid as a wet noodle.
Your mother must've walked many a wood alone. Got those nekker eyes, that nekker nose…
My mother loved me, at the least. That's nothing any witcher can claim.
Your mama…
Your taunts? I've heard dogs retch things more profound. Hear how pathetic and stupid you sound?
Well, how then is this for a clever tongue-twister - you're a bumbotching, blackened bile-filled blister!
Hear how pathetic and stupid you sound?
Fine. Let's start.
Oooh! My knees quake like a carnival rattle!
Let's get on with this ridiculous battle.
I'm a top taunter, the best around - not one to be beaten by some inbred hound!
Count me in. Sign me up.
Don't want to fight just now.
Should you change your mind, look in on us again.
Rather not fight just now.
Mancomb? Odd name.
Mancomb? First I've ever encountered that name.
One should never judge an opponent by his name. Master Mancomb is a saddler, though a valiant one at that. His blows are as fierce as his ripostes are sharp.
Do you wish to jump in?
Considering it.
So you're not surprised, consider this as well - here intellect counts as much as strength.
You see, Mancomb is no ordinary fighter.
Ready to fight?
Somethin's rank.
*Sniff sniff sniff* Eurgh.
Nothin' doin', somethin' reeks around here.

Then the kikimore princess summoned all her loyal sisters and off they went! Together they charged the enemy trying to harm their queen.
– “The Kikimore Princess and the Mountain Giants”
Cornelius Briggs (dwarven children’s fable, fragment)

It is unknown how exactly it is kikimores communicate with each other. Autopsies are hampered by the high toxicity of their subjects. Scholars have established that kikimores do not seem to possess any detectable auricles. One amateur researcher, Count di Salvaress, put forth a theory in his treatise “A Microscope Among Monsters” suggesting kikimores have a highly developed sense of smell and use airborne particles undetectable to humans to transmit information. This theory has yet to be proved or disproved.

Kikimore warriors defend their nests from attackers. They attack somewhat slower than kikimore workers. They are able to spew streams of caustic venom a great distance and leap to attack. This venom is highly unique in that it reacts with a witcher's body to raise the level of his potion toxicity. They are covered with thick, hard armor which easily deflects blows from even the sharpest sword.

Kikimore warriors are protected by swarms of workers which obey their orders until they are themselves eradicated.

They are completely immune to the effects of the Axii Sign, but vulnerable to Igni, oils and bombs harming insectoids and blows dealt by a silver sword.
Kikimore Warrior
Impresario
I would hate to come off as impertinent, but was it not you who won the tourney, Sir Graylocks?
Sir de Peyrac-Peyran dead… How the mighty fall.
You'd best behave, friend. You're in Beauclair, see?
Ugh, the dungboots that visit our town. They come but to pour wine down their peasant gullets and start quarrels.
Did you hear? Some stranger from the North won the tourney. They say he's a… witchman, or something of the sort…
Have you heard? It's raining cows at the Ardaiso quarry! Not frogs, not cats and dogs, but cows!
I tell you, no man knows the day or the hour!
The merchant, the one so giddy the hanse let him go? He drank himself stupid, fell in the lake and drowned!
Whoa! Calm down!
You must loosen up, else you'll pop a cork.
Ahoy, ahoy.
I don't give a fig one way or the other.
You don't say?!
Boor!
Your muttering speaks volumes.
Did you say something?
You can drive the rube from the village, but you'll never drive the village out of the rube!
Under Duke Raymund's rule, such troubles were simply unimaginable…
Do you know White Wolf is the best of all beverages, the tastiest of all tonics and the meatiest of all meals?
Marlene
What is this?!
For the Beast, what bait will you use? We've not many rams, and virgins fewer still!
Did you see, witcher?! Vampires all about! Every-diddly-where!
My two coppers? Get your bum out of here, quick. The duquessa is apt to change her mind.
Hullo, welcome, greetings!
Ahoy!
Jacquette

Wandering about the slopes of Mount Gorgon, Geralt came upon some grim, foreboding ruins. He set about exploring them and nearly tripped over a corpse. As always, he searched the body for a journal or letter that could shed some light on the circumstances of the individual's death. This time, too, this routine paid off. He found a journal and a key…
The journal detailed an unsuccessful experiment that had resulted in Bastoy Prison being destroyed. The witcher also learned of a chest full of gold that remained hidden within the ruins.
Geralt located the chest. The key he had found with the journal worked like a charm. So the witcher scooped up the gold and ran off to spend it!
Read the journal.
Find the treasure.
The Toussaint Prison Experiment
Wait here.
Ah!
I'm here.
This belong to you, maybe?
It did. But you may keep it. I've a new one.
I do not know you. I've done you no harm.
Yet first you butchered a bruxa who was dear to me. Now you pursue me. Why?
You've killed four innocent people. At least.
And you? How many innocents have you cut down?
Many.
Plenty. Even more of the guilty, though. You're next.
Hm, I think not. You see, I've something to do still.
More murders?
Just one.
Not counting yours.
None.
I don't kill innocents. Murderers, though? You bet.
I'll soon be done. I've but one left. And you, should you not stand down.
And once you're done, intend to leave, go kill somewhere else?
No. I intend to live.
Happily ever after.
Not here to talk about me.
Yet that is exactly what we are doing. So, did they send you after me? Who are they?
What do you mean, "they"? Duchess hired me. You've been murdering her subjects.
Hmhmhmhm, is it as simple as that?
I would ask you to convey to the duchess that I've but one victim left, but…
You'll not get the chance.
Conversation's not about me.
Ach!
What the botch?
Ugh!
Aaauugh!
What was that?!
I won't let you kill again!
Some knavish knight abducted poor Jean Louis! Apparently, the rogue burned with passion for the hairdresser, but Jean Louis rejected him…
Did you hear about Madame de Bourbeau? She left her husband and ran off with some farm boy!
Two of those purportedly virtuous knights pummeled each other over a dockside whore. Apparently, they argued who would go first!
A Beast like that probably has no one to split a bottle with.
What is they call you? Gervant?
Come, I must give you a squeeze, hero!
Our liberator! Geralt of Rivia!
Drink and be merry!
I wish you health! Glory! Honor!
He's gone mad! Positively mad!
Watch those hands!

The best defense against spotted wights? Stay calm and leave them alone.
– fragment of a treatise on spotted wights by Roderick Giligan.

Spotted wights were a subspecies of wight which the witchers drove to extinction. They were larger than their unspotted kin and owed their names to their numerous blotches and effusions. Spotted wights would most often dwell in derelict cemeteries and empty wildernesses, yet at times took to living in abandoned human domiciles. There they would indulge in their greatest passion: creating brews from their own emissions.

When not disturbed, spotted wights would not act aggressively. If threatened, however, they became very dangerous indeed. In the colder months or when faced with an unseasonable chill, they would slip into a state of lethargy, making them easy targets. Even during their active periods, it is said the witchers found a surefire way of besting them, based around careful casting of the Yrden Sign – or at least, so claims witcher lore…

Whenever on the one hand witchers swear they have driven a certain species of monster into extinction and one the other someone claims to have seen a member of that species walking around in apparent health, most likely we are dealing with a curse. This rule of thumb showed its worth with the spotted wight from the Trastamara estate. It turned out this creature was in fact a woman transformed into a monster by a curse many years prior, as punishment for refusing food and shelter to a wandering beggar.
Spotted Wights
I'm not at all fond of that chain you wear. It clashes horribly with my dress.
But it's my dynastic crest…
I don't like it.
Very well, darling. I shall put it away.
My mother's invited us to afternoon tea tomorrow. She would like very much to meet you.
But I told you, my dear. We're expected tomorrow at a Mandragora soirée.
Well… take care, you two… love birds.
Good luck.
Noticed any changes? Any symptoms?
Noticed any changes? Anything strange on your body? Troubling symptoms?
Ah… Hm, how shall I put this? Ahem… I've grown some feathers… well, down, to be precise.
Whereabouts?
Ahhh…. Why mention it. It's such a minor a problem.
Personally, I like it.
Greetings, witcher.
You're well? Everything seem in order?
We are. And it is. I thank you again, Geralt.
For a boy, I'm most fond of Vivaldi. And our daughter we shall name Marilla.
Yes, my beloved, yes.
Get out! Begone!
Out! Now!
Yes? You've a concern?
Our bank is the pride of all Beauclair.
Good day, sir.
What is it you seek here?
Grab him!
Cianfanelli!
We will gut you!
Came to get the horses. Probably ready to escape.
Gotta get into the keep…
Aaarghh!
Onward!
Argh. Bandit lice…
Where is she?!
Move, witcher!
Witcher, we must find Rhena! Quickly!
Come, Geralt, we must hurry.
Gotta move on. Get into the keep…
Need to get into the keep.
They shall pay. For everything.
Run to Fourfingers! Someone's to die today…
Someone fetch Loth Halfbreed. The witcher wants to die!
Summon Starling Straggen! This one wants to die!
This won't hurt a bit.
I'm coming for you.
I'll pinch a loaf on your grave.
Tartlicker! Rotmunch!
Quick! Quicker!
Calmly… no need to get worked up.
Cursery!
Gibbering gallbladders and a gaggle of guardsmen!
Around here, it's wine, wine and more wine! But me, I prefer brandy.
La dee dee dah dah!
Ooh! Here he comes - our hero! Geralt the Riv!
Finish him good!
One, two! And through and through!
Snicker-snack! Snicker-snack! Break the rotten bum hole's back!
Come rain or sun, it shall be fun!
Death! Pain! You shall be slain!
Am I invisible?!
Try that on me, you boots of the puss!
Bloody blazes, calm down!
Onward, onward, onward!
I've got something of my own to pull out!
He's some sort of mage!
If that's your stance, then this is mine…
Much better!
Brandy and bosoms - my two true loves.
Catch some winks, grab some tit - it's what life's all about, isn't it?
Blood and Wine
No touching until you pay!
Well? Merely browsing or ready to pull it out?
What's your wish? A dash of wine and some slap and tickle?
I can see you slurping me with your eyes, White One!

Geralt read it, and all became clear. An unhappy, unrequited love had pushed the young man to commit suicide. Ah, I know so many stories that echo this one… Yet this one differed from the others in that evil powers were involved. The journal also mentioned a stash of buried jewels. So Geralt resolved to learn more and directed his steps towards the estate the diary described.
Geralt explored the Cutterin residence and found the treasure mentioned in the journal. Content with this surprising find, he set off in search of new challenges.

Wandering about the primeval forest that covered the duchy's frontier, the witcher made a discovery most macabre. Deep in the forest, a small hut. Alongside the hut, a tree. Upon the tree, a hanged man. On the ground directly beneath the corpse lay a journal.
Read the notes.
Find the jewels.
The Suffering of Young Francois
My deepest apologies.
Back to work. I must get back to work.
Lebioda's lacerations! My son's been made a squire!
Ah, if I could only afford that horse for my son… and armor…

They say the dead like quiet. I don’t know about the dead, but wights certainly do.
– Heinrich Von Grott

Though wights are ghastly and threatening in appearance, one should not approach them with sword drawn or attack them unprovoked. Left alone, they present no serious danger to anyone and are far more interested in mixing noxious brews in cauldrons than in fighting. This species mainly lives around ancient burial sites, though they have also been spotted near more recently-founded cemeteries and wherever mass graves can be found.

Wights spend the winter months in a state of lethargy very similar to human sleep. They live strictly solitary lives -- in fact, it is practically unheard of for these creatures to appear in groups. Yet when they fear their territory is threatened (and it is enough for one to step foot in a wight’s territory for it to feel threatened), wights transform into dangerous foes and even abandon their solitary ways to summon other monsters to their aid.

It is a certainty that if a wight finds itself in danger, it will immediately spew out an ectoplasmic solution which near instantaneously transforms into barghests. These beasts obey the wight and attack anyone it deems a foe. If one of them is killed, the wight tries to replace it at once.

The best strategy when fighting such a wight is to take out the monsters guarding it with the Axii sign before attacking the wight itself. Wights are resistant to poison, but vulnerable to silver.
Wights
Wine, wine, wine!
Hullo, hullo!
Lebioda turned mud into must. Are you familiar with the tale?
The Prophet Lebioda was a great wine drinker, too!
Count Beledal's Guest
Head to the Pheasantry, they'll put some meat on your bones!
Eat something, nourish yourself, you need color, you look horrid!
You don't look good. No, not good at all!
Gray as doodle, scrawny as doodle…
Chapeau bas, witcher! True class you showed! Many thanks!
This is an outrage!
Stands are full, I'm sorry.
I shall file a complaint! I've friends in high places!
Please give them my condolences.
Bain

Pussy cat, pussy cat, where have you been?
I’ve been to Cintra to look at the queen
Pussy cat, pussy cat, what did you there?
Run, fool, that’s not a cat but a panther!
– rare variant of a traditional folk rhyme

Panthers are dangerous predators found in forests and other woodlands. They are quick, agile and, like all cats, diabolically cunning. In many less-than-thoroughly-urbanized areas, folk still believe panthers are the stranded souls of those who die in their sleep. Superstition thus holds anyone perishing in this way should be dragged to the nearest woods and left there without a burial. The panther-spirit of the deceased may then devour its own body, thereby passing on to the nether realms.

This belief must be eradicated by any means, for it leads to epidemics of cholera and other contagious diseases born of rotting corpses.

Besides, it is patently ridiculous, given panthers are not necrophages and will not consume carrion of any sort. They prefer more spry and lively prey, such as deer or even humans, provided they are not ill and do not stink too badly.

Panthers (and their tawny-coated cousins, mountain lions) are incredibly swift and able to sneak up on prey undetected to gain the advantage of surprise.

As soon as they enter open terrain, they leap to attack with astonishing speed, mauling their prey with their sharp claws, long teeth and the sheer force of their momentum.

Panthers are known to retreat mid-fight, yet do not let yourself be fooled into a false sense of security. This is but a ruse to allow them to attack again, by surprise. Never drop your guard until you see the animal drop dead.

Panthers are vulnerable to the effects of all the Signs, as well as bombs and oils.
Panthers
The hanses - you aim to grapple with them?
No time for chit-chat. I've work waiting on the table! Ptooey.
Witchers' blades… masterpieces.
Tah rah rah ree rar rah. Tah rah…
Rock Troll
Count Beledal's welfare, that's what matters most.
Keep your eyes peeled. Safety's key.
Saying you're the duke of this, the duke of that… you're the duke of dog diddle!
I'm going to say it with my hands - watch your stones!
What? Botch off, I'm working here!
Ehh?
Merchant
Witcher.
Greetings.
Hey!
Geralt… I'd never wish to give the impression I do not enjoy your company - the truth is quite the opposite, in fact - however…
Yeah, I know. Dettlaff's not likely to show up long as I'm here. But five minutes won't save us, will it?
I suppose not. I was wrong to press you to go. You wished to ask something…?
But while we're at it, be so good and explain to me how it was you acquired that startling scar on your face. Forgive me for being direct, but it's tormented me for some time, now.
Ugh, long story, actually. Let's just say I struck up with some unsavory folk. No worries, though. I'll get out of it.
Just wondering… what if Dettlaff doesn't show?
He'll show.

Ugh… Tell me, how's this work? When I need a short answer, concise, quick, you're likely to give me a scholarly lecture. But when I could use some details, elaboration, all's I get is a few grunts. What's that about?
Allow me to explain. When speaking of facts, tangible matters, I do indeed strive to express myself precisely and at length.

However, when our discussions center on affairs of the intuition or things vampiric, my utterances are indeed towards the taciturn. For even the longest discourse would not allow me to explain to my interlocutor any issue of this purview satisfactorily.
Therefore, I repeat - Dettlaff will show. Sooner or later.
What happens if Dettlaff doesn't show?
Take care, Regis.
So long.
How'd you and Dettlaff meet anyway?
Been meaning to ask you… how'd you and Dettlaff meet?
Hm, hm. A somewhat… uncomfortable subject.
I'm all ears and I got time.

As you well know, during my teething years I had a… spell… during which I abused blood. Among vampiric youth I was, all false modesty aside, rather popular. I ran with the plasma crowd. I made a great many acquaintances… one of whom was Dettlaff.

But… our paths soon diverged. You see, our band had an appetite for chasing youthful capers. Blood-guzzling contests, that sort of thing - "let's turn into bats and terrify the ladies." Dettlaff thought it all foolish. He was right, of course… though I only came to understand this later.
Sorry… just can't imagine you as a young vampire rabble-rouser, renegade, punk.
You know of our exceedingly long lifespans… They allow us plenty of time to change. I, for one, thank the gods for that.
Yes, Geralt?
Greetings.
Hmm…
You're pushin' it, friend.
Gonna kill you.
Fuck!
I'm runnin' outta patience.
That's right.
Your choice, you pleb.
Wight
Fabricio

Well, since it seems this hair won’t be pulling up any knights in shining armor, might as well put it to some use.
– the last words of Longlocks.

Everyone knows love stories can have tragic endings, but few would think this also applies to princesses from fairy tales created to relive a set happy ending over and over again. Longlocks had the misfortune of becoming just such an unlikely tragic heroine. After the duke’s daughters grew up and the Land of a Thousand Fables went feral, Longlocks, whose prince never came and who suffered greatly from her loneliness, decided to hang herself by her own braid. After she died, her ghost stayed to haunt the castle in which she had awaited her suitor.
Longlocks
I knew you'd not abandon us in our hour of need, Sir Geralt.
Eric van Vrog
You're tormented. By what?
Forgive me, but I must ask directly - are you a man? I… I no longer trust my senses.
Not exactly. I'm a witcher. Quite a few folk think I don't deserve to be classified as a member of the human species. Know some personally.
A witcher…? But no, nor can you help me.
We'll see. Just tell me what the problem is.
No. I'm a witcher.
Yes.
Yes. Meaning, I'm physical, no specter or vision, if that's what you fear. Don't trust your senses? Why?
A foulness, a demon or wraith, haunts me. Grants me no rest. It wants something, I sense this, but know not what. Each day it appears, tarries, then leaves. It's here now - there, beyond the trees.
Don't see a thing.
Of course not. It cannot be seen.
Yet you see it…?
Only when I drink the brew. Which brings a pain to my head, nausea. But I endure these to keep an eye on the wraith, my tormentor.
What's the demon look like?
This demon of yours… can you describe it?
It is an enormous horse, its hoof beats pounding in the dark. It gallops to me, stops, stares… then runs on.
Sure it's not just a wild horse, run-of-the-mill?
The creature is not of this world. When it gazes at me, a terrible chill pervades my soul.
It is evil condensed, its eyes black, void… Each time it comes, terror grips me, I cease what I'm doing, still my breath and heart.
The brew - what's it made of?
What's your brew made of? Gotta wonder what's causing such strong visions. You drop in some mushroom? Chumbertub? Dancing dewlap?
Close. The common graytop. I see you know your herbs.
Graytop? Variety's extinct, if I recall correctly.
Nearly, but not quite. I was able to grow a few from dried spores. I'd hoped a brew of graytop would reveal this nightmare. I was not wrong.
Far as I know, graytop produces some powerful side effects. Though it can, in fact, reveal the hidden, the immaterial…
Yes, I see the evil… Better that than to know it is there, but not know where.
A king's ransom, that!
I feel we could agree, were you to go a few lower.
Fine. You seem sure something's out there. I'll see what I can do.
Start by taking a look around.
I'll try to help.
You're taking hallucinogens, a steady diet. Stop and your specter problem'll go away. Farewell.
Stop taking hallucinogens. Problem'll go away on its on.
Let's talk about my pay.
Need to talk about how much I'll get paid, first.
Is it gold you want?
Orens or Novigrad crowns. Florens'll work, too.
I've none of any coin. I've nothing, in fact. Just… potatoes in the cellar. A good crop this year. Tend to this quickly, completely, and several sacks will be yours. Agreed?
If that's the case, no pay required. Need those potatoes more than I do.
Don't need any pay.
Fine. Potatoes it is.
Don't have a choice, I guess. Potatoes it is, but how many?
Unthinkable. What good is your aid if I starve come winter? Take what I offer. or begone and leave me in peace.
Agreed. That many I can spare.
Witcher. Will you help me after all?
La, la la, la laa la la!
Drinking's an art! Not just any slob can do it.
Now what's his type doing here…?
Lebioda's wounds!
Thanks, good game.
Bollock blisters, what hurts most is fuckin' Skellige won. But as they say, "tough shite." Congrats!
I won! Now youse can shove all this Skellige mince up yer arses!
You won 'cause you played better, not because the faction's weak.
Aye, right, I knows what I saw.
Well played, thank you for a scintillating game. I trust my victory has convinced all doubters of the value of the new faction.
Ye won 'cause ye played better. Even if ye hadnae played as ploughing Skellige, ye woulda won anyhow. Congrats all the same - Yaki Rafiberg's no sore loser.
C'mon, lads! Let's get soused!
No, you must stay, for I wish to treat you all to a tipple! We must toast the premier of the new faction! And if anyone wishes to play a friendly match of gwent, I see no reason why not!
Thank you for everything, witcher.
No problem, had fun.
No problem.
Didn't all go as planned.
Don't think that went exactly as you'd planned.
What matters is we played gwent, and I presented the Skellige faction.
You proved yourself a true gwent master. Here, the grand prize - you earned it.
Thank you very much, Count.
Yet most important of all to me is that you fulfilled my brother's wish, so I would like to give you something else.
The most precious card of his collection. May it serve you well.
Thanks. It's an honor, count.
I am glad to have met you. I desire to do one more thing for you, witcher. Such is my nature. Is there any way I could be of service?
During the tournament I lost my silver sword. I'd like to get it back, because that's how I earn my wages.
I believe I shall be able to help.
Would you be so kind, good sir, as to agree to return Geralt his sword - in exchange for a blade once belonging to the famed knight Rydygier?
Yes, but the sword of Rydygier in the sands of time sank…
I assure you, that is far from the truth. In that case… it's settled.
Fine is this blade, may it continue to well serve you.
Thank you, count. And you, sir.
Generosity is a virtue.
Thank you once more for deigning to take part in my little tournament. I hope we shall meet again.
Who knows… farewell.
I'm sorry you did not manage to qualify for the finals. I'd hoped to face you, but participation alone counts for something. Here, a consolation prize.
Thanks.

Never seen a vampire like that in my life.
– Geralt of Rivia, witcher

Protofleders are relatives of fleders which came from the world of the higher vampires to our own during the Conjunction of the Spheres.

The members of this species are characterized by their considerable strength and agility as well as the strange glow they emit, a trait most likely tied to their otherworldly nature. Protofleders have never had significant contact with the outside world, having spent their entire time on our planet in the Unseen Elder’s cave, whose atmosphere is very similar to that of their home world.
Protofleders
Drunken Master
Banquets and wine are rather suited for pleasant mirth.
Night, love and wine counsel no half-hearted measures.
Do you read poetry, sir?
Naught is nearly as fun as a pun.
We should drop our tools, occupy the building, say fiddlesticks to it all.
If this keeps up, next the rivers will flow with blood!
If that's the way it is, I'm off. I won't do it. No botchy way.
Crushed by a cow? Shameful. Not fit to be used on the gravestone…
Nothing but work, work, work. And for what? For fum-diddly-nothing, that's what!
Never. No, never would I have agreed to this work had I known it would be like this.
What if instead… the rivers were to flow with ale?
A slyzard, sure… two slyzards, blast, why not make it ten?!
To trust a freak at his word? And if another cow kerduddles one of us?
Bumbotch this job. I'd never have signed on if I'd known it'd be like this.
Grave Hag
Stablemaster
Master witcher?
Top o' the day!
My sister saw where this one beggar buried some gold coins!
Wanna go fish in the channel?
La la la la la laa…
Owww!
Help! Help!
Fuck, it itches! Ploughin' whore gave me somethin'.
Watch where you're walkin'!
Witcher, I heard you defeated Filibert Fourfingers' hanse! Respect!
Witcher! Remember, the camerlengo pays out a handsome reward for each hanse you despatch!
A courageous heart overcomes all hindrance!
To lose one's good name… it is worse than death!
You wrested Fox Hollow from Loth Halfbreed's clutches! You deserve a monument for that!
Your luck has run out, dog.
I am the punishment for your many sins!
I shall wash away that insult to our duchy's majesty with your blood!
Your luck has run out, dog.
I shall wash away that insult to our duchy's majesty with your blood!
Die!
I am the punishment for your many sins!
Die!
Forward! Side by side! Arm in arm!
Forward! Side by side! Arm in arm!
How might I aid you?
Yes, fellow knight and friend?
Don't lose spirit!
Don't lose spirit!
Enough! Or I shall resort to harsher means!
Witcher!
You scare me.
What happened to you?

The old fool came home all black and blue, claiming kikimores had attacked him in the woods. Who does he take me for?! His mates worked him over because he’d cheated at gwent. If it’d been kikimores, he’d be dead. And I’d have peace at last.
– Lavinia, wife of a Beauclair innkeeper

Kikimores form colonies, making them similar to communal insects such as ants. A kikimore colony is ruled by a queen and organized into something of a social hierarchy. Kikimore workers take care of hunting food and bringing it back to the nest, while kikimore warriors defend the nest against attackers.

A worker on its own can be easily killed by even a weak person or a child. It is rare indeed, however, to come across an isolated individual, for kikimore workers usual move in groups of a few to a dozen or so members. The only defense against a swarm of kikimores available to a normal person is to flee. And not even that is guaranteed to work.

Kikimore workers listen to orders given by kikimore warriors. On command, a swarm of workers might begin burrowing tunnels near potential prey to allow for a surprise mass attack. Eliminate the warrior guiding a swarm, however, and the workers will disperse and cease digging.

Kikimore workers are nimbler and quicker than warriors.

They show complete immunity to the Axii Sign, and when they dig tunnels, they are invulnerable to all the other Signs as well. Poison also does them no harm.

A good method for fighting them is to use the Igni Sign as well as oils and bombs meant to damage insectoids.
Kikimore Workers
Whoa there, wobbly walker!
The duchess means for that witcher to settle here permanently. She gave him a vineyard for that very reason. Now that we've him to protect us, all those erring knights - woosh! - can retire early!
During the vampire attack, the Belles stuffed garlic into every nook and cranny. Now the clients want discounts for the "disturbing aroma"!
Some pervert yanked off Reginald's hallowed stones. They say the deviant runs about the docks, scaring old women with his stony privates!
Why, you! Achoo! Dallgummy, boogered myself something horrible.
You spout poppycock. That's the long and the short of it.
Is that you? The tourney's champion?
Sheep shenanigans! I can't see a thing through these cataracts!
But a few drops of wine, and lo and behold - I see better!
Me, I didn't see a single vampire…
Sonny, is that you?
Hi-diddily-ho!
Don't hurt me, please!
Ghost

While seeking a bit of respite amidst the forests that covered the slopes of Mount Gorgon, Geralt ran into… a dead man and a pack of barghests! Once he had dealt with the spectral canines, he decided to search the pockets of the unlucky traveler. The witcher hoped he would find something that would shed some light on the deceased's last days alive.

The dead man proved none other than a treasure hunter. That, at least, is how I would like to think of and term him (for there is no honor in speaking ill of the dead). His notes indicated that he and some others of his ilk had dug up an elven cemetery near the village of Fox Hollow. However, they had dug up one jewel too many…
When the feelings of guilt and shame had grown to be too much, and the expedition's members had begun, one by one, to disappear, Alistair Carnarvon, for that was our deceased hero's name, had decided to inform a group of scholars at Castel Graupian of his find. Said scholars, he believed, would look to the ancient necropolis and extend their care over it. Alas, he had never managed to reach the scholars, and the treasures he had left behind in the camp were now ownerless…

Geralt found the camp as well as a field that had been dug up thoroughly. Strewn about it were the urns and remains of elves who had been buried there. The chest Alistair had left behind contained no burial jewels. It was, however, full of gold and highly interesting diagrams. The witcher concluded he was free to take it all, and in doing so he would not disturb the Aen Seidhe who lay there in eternal slumber.
Read Carnarvon's journal.
Find the treasure hidden in the treasure hunters' camp.
The Curse of Carnarvon

At a sacred site of the cult of the Prophet Lebioda, Geralt stumbled upon the remains of one of the prophet's most fervent adherents - a monk known as the Great Beggar. Alas, the poor man had been bricked up alive and left to starve in the wall of the chapel, so his restless soul promptly attacked the witcher. Geralt knew that the only way to help the Great Beggar's soul to find peace was to give his remains a proper burial.
Luckily, Geralt did not have to search far for an appropriate sarcophagus. He laid the Great Beggar's bones in a grave within the chapel, thus securing his rattled soul's eternal rest.
Find an empty sarcophagus and place the bones in it.
The Words of the Prophets Are Written on Sarcophagi
Argoin
Look!
Ah!
Your Highness.
Your Grace.
Her Enlightened Highness.
Your Grace.
Your Highness.
It's an honor.
What's this about?
Monsters! Monsters, there, in the cave!
We managed to flee. But Hugo remains inside!
Hugo?
Our brother! He's still in there, inside!
Help us! Find him! We'll pay you for your toil!
What attacked you? Exactly.
Notice what attacked you?
There was no time! We ran for the exit as soon as we felt the earth quiver! But Hugo, well, he went the other way.
So, monsters crawl out of the ground?
I… I suppose… In truth, I don't know. We just ran, did not look back.
Why'd you go in there to begin with?
Why'd you even go in there?
We… lost our way…
Mh. Mistake that cave for the highroad?
By the hair on my chinny chin chin, what difference does it make whether we went for a stroll or to gather sewants? Hugo remains inside, in grave danger! That's what matters!
Will you go in after him or not? Every second could be vital!
You the ones looking for someone to escort you?
You post that notice? About an escort?
Yes, we did! And not without cause, it seems! We waited some days, yet when none answered, we risked the expedition unaccompanied.
Fools we were. We'd have done better to show patience, wait… Poor Hugo - left to an unknown fate!
Let's talk about my… fee.
I could look into it… but it'll cost you.
How much would you take?
Alas, that is not an amount we could ever muster. Might you take a little less?
This, this is more than we hoped to spend, but minimally so. Might you drop your price a bit?
You're back! Will you find Hugo? Save him?
He's still in there! Alone! He'll likely die if you don't help!
Fine. I'll look for him. You two stay out here.
Fine. See what I can do.
No time, can't help.
Come on. You two made it out. Your brother will too. I'm not needed here.
But--
It's no use, Auguste. The witcher clearly refuses to aid us. Perhaps another will read the notice, come along.
But should you change your mind, we'll be waiting here!
I'm not needed here.
My fee - let's talk.
We are not fashioned of gold. We cannot afford this amount.
A reasonable price.
Fine. I'll help.
Greetings.
What do you want?
{*Slurp slurp*}
Why don't y'all just get off my back!
Oy!
Bobbery!
Help! Good folk!
No! No! Leave me be!
Monsters attacking!
Run! Flee! They'll cut us down!
Not your concern, neither of those things.
Neither's your concern.
No concern of ours, you say… Perhaps not. But we've got eyes… and can see those razors you got on your back right clear.
He's a witcher. Boholt and his boys, he's their mate. Heard of him. Geralt of Rivia's the name.
We'll take it on together.
We'll go at it as a bunch. Just stay clear of my sword.
Right, now, lads. You've heard the specialist.
There.
Grab your ballies! Shoot the bitch down!
All good and fine, but the monster's not in its nest. Gotta track it down first.
Not at all necessary, Geralt. We looked into it, gave it a think. Traders used tannin to lure the beast. Who says we can't do the same?
You got any tannin?
Came into a bit, aye. Here! Willin' to do the honors?
Use your crossbows. Keep her on the ground. Good idea.
D'you say "her"?
It's a female, yeah.
Hear that, lads? We've a learned witcher here. A hundred spans out an' he's spotted what the lizard's got between its legs.
Right, now, lads. You've heard the specialist. Ready your crossbows.
Use your crossbows.
Beast has to die. We work together, we'll make quick work of it.
After all I told you of Iocaste, you would murder her?! Oh, you will regret this, friend! I know folk! I shall tell them you slew the last surviving specimen!

Sorry, master di Salvaress. Actually, not sorry. A monster's a monster. Silvery, plaid or polka-dotted… last or next-to-last specimen - doesn't matter. It's a dangerous predator that kills humans. Enough said.
Herbalists, alchemists - I know many! They will despise you! I shall tell them of a heartless cur who cares not an ounce for balance in nature. You shall pay arms and legs for their wares. More!
Somebody plug this lordlin's gob, eh? Right, master witcher. How do we aim to fight the filth?
We've crossbows. Could ply it with bolts while you do the hack and slash. Or all go at it as a bunch, blades in hand, fire in our hearts. You decide, you're the one with experience.
Beast needs to die. Let's do it.
Don't need any more coin.
Don't need any more. Rather you paid it out to the families of your pet's victims.
Noble of you, master. I shall take the advice to heart.
Iocaste has flown her nest.
Must've sensed a threat. Likely to return eventually, though.
She'll return. Always does. I suspect I might even know where she's gone. I tracked her a way and believe she might have found a new mate. It's an ordinary basilisk, not a silvery one…
But something might come of it, who knows. Iocaste could lay new eggs. Perhaps produce an entirely new crossbreed?
Sure hope not. Take care.
Thanks.
Thanks.
You spared Iocaste, I thank you. And be assured I'll take great care she not dine on any other souls.
Gotta try harder, figure out a way to keep folk out of this area.
That I shall do. Master, you must accept more, be it a symbolic sum. Had you not come along, the Reavers would surely have slain my Iocaste.
Basilisk lives for now. We're not gonna kill it.
A witcher defendin' a beast? Ever seen that, lads? You like them peaches?
Argh… No scrappin' with filth today, it seems. But, but… you made some mention o' coin, as I recall.
I did indeed. And a word once given…
Your share, witcher.
Hahaha! Easiest job I've ever done. Godspeed, witcher. Strange workin' with you. Strange but nice.
Godspeed, boys.
Basilisk's not to be killed.
A professional. Good you came along. Can take on the brute together. Talk is the venom's somethin' horrifyin'.
Could use another pair of hands. Fee what we've gotten from the guild, we'll share it fair and square. You in?
Gentlemen, this hurts my ears and pains my heart! You aim to kill Iocaste? It cannot be! The creature is protected!
If you fear to lose the guild's reward, I shall repay it. And reward you doubly to leave the beast be! You cannot slay the last living specimen of a near extinct subspecies.
Willin' to pay, are you? Long as we do nothin'? That's rather novel. What say you to that, master? Far as I know, beast's culled the human race by five already.
Geralt of Rivia. I'm a witcher. Know your brethren in arms - Boholt, Kennet and Desbrut. Newboy, too.
Aaah, you're that witcher! Aye, Boholt mentioned you. Said you swing a mean sword.
Geralt of Rivia. We've got mutual acquaintances.
Jamor, Auwry, prepare the equipment. Beast's wandered off somewheres. We gotsta lure it back.
And who might you be?
Funny. About to ask you the same.
They call us the Reavers.
Reavers? Wouldn't happen to hail from Crinfrid, would you?
Aye, we do. But how's it you know? And again - who the hell are you?
Corpse… a mercenary's, seems. Shredded. Basilisk has left its nest, clearly.
Butchers! This is barbarous! What did she ever do to you?! Stop! My Iocaste! Do not slay her!
Wretch's got somethin' in that skulls of 'ers. Not about to roost in its nest with warriors on the prowl after it.
It's afeared, all right. On account it senses we're true Reavers!
Damned right!
The vault is closed.
It's all shut up. Step away, please.
Death has taken Her Grace. We must drown our sorrows in drink…
This marks the duchy's end. Its final hour!
Wine - sunlight captured in a bottle.
Art is not life's bread and butter but its fruit and wine.
Go on! Kill me! Do the deed!
My, my… That is quite the tale.
Ehh, poppycock…
The Monnart Brothers now make cognac so exquisite the emperor himself has put in an order!
That witcher's been here before… As I recall, he slew a few beasts and stashed a pile of coin at Cianfanelli's!
De Bourbeau's got horns from here to Mont Crane! His wife's been frolicking about with some stablehand!
Yes, sir?
Greetings and welcome!
Bah!
Hmph.
This must be a mistake!
Oh!
You can't pull one over on me, witcher. I can see you're a killer.
Stocks and the whip await those running riot! Our duchy values peace and quiet!
Geralt of Rivia, slayer of the Beast. I am in your debt. We all are.
Look lively! Rush at him, boys!
Mumsy!
You're one fast son of your mum!
Did that hurt? Dammit, did it?!
Toussaint!
No!
Come, now, keep calm!
He shall not escape!
Witcher! You'll put someone's eye out!
Spells! He's hexing hard!
Is that how it's to be?!
That's more like it.
Geralt of Rivia, perchance?
At your service, witcher.

According to some philosophers, everything we do in life leaves a permanent trace in the delicate matter which makes up our souls. Evil deeds, especially harm done to innocent creatures, can torment the soul of a sinner and cause it to remain restless, even after death.

While traveling through Toussaint, Geralt discovered there might be a grain of truth in these theories and folk beliefs. He came across a hermit whose sleep was troubled by some invisible phantom.

Geralt determined this phantom was an umbra, the ghost of a recently-deceased knight who had committed a terrible deed while alive and now visited the hermit to demand forgiveness. In his wraithly form he drank her blood and systematically deprived her of life energy.

The umbra appeared to the hermit as a horse, for the evil deed the knight had committed was to flog his own mount to death. The knight’s spirit was unaware of the demonic role he had assumed in the afterlife.

Geralt managed to figure out the key to freeing the knight’s ghost was to forgive him in the name of the hermit.

An umbra is merely an unclean conscience, one tormented by guilt and unforgiven wrongs. A man wallows in sin with loose women and can’t sleep at night, then invents hokey about some umbra or phantom and blabbers about it at the tavern.
– Sabine of Dal, mystic and priestess of the Prophet Lebioda.

Geralt determined this phantom was an umbra, the ghost of a recently-deceased knight who had committed a terrible deed while alive and now visited the hermit to demand forgiveness. In his wraithly form he drank her blood and systematically deprived her of life energy.

The umbra appeared to the hermit as a horse, for the evil deed the knight had committed was to flog his own mount to death. The knight’s spirit was unaware of the demonic role he had assumed in the afterlife.

Such an umbra could be defeated with a silver blade, preferably one coated in wraith oil.
Umbra
Handled that kid pretty well.
Finding the right approach - that's the trick to dealing with children.
Mh, yeah, saw that… Meaning, the right thing to bribe them with.
Red door. One the bootblack mentioned.
We shall talk later. Let's find Dettlaff. We're close, I can feel it.
We've no time to lose. It's not far, from what the lad said.
Sure hope we don't scare him off…
This festival of vanity is an offense to the gods!
Thou shalt not muzzle the mouth of truth!
Innkeep
This is it for you, pal!
Come on! Come tae daddy!
Scalp the wee shite!
And what might you want?
Welcome to Cianfanelli Bank.
Get out. That's your lot, chum.
I thought we'd seen the last o' your mug.
What can I do for ye?
All in order?
Pass a glass, fast!
Tipple a tiddle of wine!
Do you know the colors I would see on the duchy's banners? Red, white and rosé!
Never you worry! The air here is such that one is never hungover!
What's the hurry?
Greetings.
I must look to the pickers, make certain they don't snip clusters touched by mold…
Of course I can tell they malinger, but who am I to judge?
Ugh. Stinks.
Water-logged, both hands amputated. Body was quartered, just as I thought.
[Examine chest.]
Body was chopped up after death.
Blows struck with great force, but bones sliced through, not crushed.
Creature that killed him had long claws, sharp as a witcher's blade. First sank its claws into the victim's heart.
No bruxa did this.
[Examine head.]
Laid in water for some time. Head's swollen, and something took a few bites out of it.
Hm. Something in the throat.
A pouch. Bulging with coins.
Nilfgaardian florens… from several different provinces.
If the murderer did this, means we're dealing with a sentient, thinking beast.
Nothing interesting besides the purse in his throat.
[Examine the severed hand.]
Third hand. A spare? Except it's clearly not the victim's. Guardsmen must've not noticed it as they picked everything up.
How's this possible? Still warm. Blood's still flowing?
Several monster species can regenerate. Never heard of that happening to their severed limbs, though. Or of their limbs seeming completely alive after so much time.
Examine the tissue more closely later. Might learn something.
[End examination.]
So, murderer was clearly a monster, but not a bruxa.
But then why'd the bruxa come here for the severed hand? And who does the hand belong to? Why the hell's it still warm?
Now, pouch shoved down the victim's throat - what's the significance? And why was he chopped up into pieces?
Lots of questions, no answers so far. Need to know about the other victims. I'll ask Palmerin to get me in to see the duchess.
Hand from the bag didn't belong to this victim.
Hm. Seems the bruxa was placing a third hand in her bag…
Both arms separated from the torso.
What the kusse is that?!
We've to help them! Come, follow me!
Arseritters are here already! Come, now, to arms!
Mon-- Monsters! Leg it!
Come back, cowards!
Monsters! Monsters approach!
They've demons with them!
Gods have mercy!
They will kill us all!
Heeeeelp! They'll cut us down!
Something's afoot… We must help them!
Relax. Now we wait.
Ah, our favorite vintner.
It's not him.
Big Bad Wolf
That Filibert von Wittan, Fourfingers - how did he wind up with the moniker?
He had four fingers.
Well, that's a bumload of help. I know he was missing one. What I don't know is how he lost it.
He didn't talk about it, nearly ever, didn't like to. Once he claimed some wench had bit it off. But he was drunk, so it was probably wishful thinking.
Kill the monsters which have infested the grotto.
Return to your contract giver.

Proceeding on his way, Geralt encountered one in need, as he had many times before. I must emphasize that though ostensibly cool and aloof, the witcher, in fact, has a heart of gold. Thus none should wonder that he agreed to help the anxious vintner. For a modest fee, of course.
Without a moment's hesitation Geralt plunged into the darkness of the Grey Grotto and cut to bits the monsters that had made their lair there…
…For which service he received a generous reward! Then the witcher, his spirits lifted, set off down his Path!
Vintner's Contract: Cleaning Those Hard-to-Reach Places
Greetings, greetings.
Mhm?
I've seen what the Beast does to its victims… Kill it, witcher.
I thank you, witcher. We all do.
A monster slayer - my, my…
A cat steal your brains?
What now?!
*Hawk snort* Wha?
Argh *Cough cough cough*
Know how to whistle? Just put your lips together and blow.
Any takers? Last call, then I head home.
My oh my, handsome. Banishing the Beast, that's no fuff in the undies…
Hey there, handsome!
Ask nicely!
Will you look at that!
Don't see anything here.
These're hoof prints. Not just any old horse's, either. These were left by an astral being, otherworldly. We gotta follow them.
Geralt, look! This here's definitely a clue.
Geralt, we gotta inspect this area closely. I'll look for clues. You stand there and… well, just stand.
Right.
Dead moths - often mean a phantom's nearby.
Thanks, Captain Obvious. Now what about the smell? Same whiff I caught at the cemetery in Vizima, when we were hunting ghouls.
The smell of… death.
Smells normal to me… Not taking me for a ride, are you?
Uh seriously?
All right, now I know what we're up against.
Yes?
Lovely weather.
Criminy, it better not rain.
If it rains, the fields will flood, the vines will absorb, and the wine will turn out watery…
Wha's… what's happening?
Yaaaawn - huh? What?
Ehh, ahem. Now what will you be needing that blade for, eh?
I'll blow your house down!
Sniff a pit, fiend scum!
Thrust your pike, swing your sword, eradicate the witcher horde!
Yaaawn. Pious Plegmund's beard, I'm dozing off!
Damned bedbugs. Didn't sleep a wink…
Plegmund's pubes, man! Get ahold of yourself!
Bums age like wine - meaning they go sour as vinegar!
There's never been a frown that couldn't be turned upside down!
Well, diddle my dangly!
Oh, go suck on a beetroot!

It was horrifying to watch... that gentleman suddenly turned into a ghastly beast, with claws, and... tore those men to shreds with the precision of a master butcher…
– a witness to Dettlaff's attacks

Dettlaff is a higher vampire and one of the most terrifying creatures the world has ever known. Some vampires of his sort live among men easily and inconspicuously, sometimes even gaining the respect and admiration of their community. Yet even the most civilized vampire can be incredibly dangerous if provoked, and Dettlaff... Dettlaff was far from civilized.

When in his two-legged form, Dettlaff strikes in surprising and unique ways, so one must be extremely alert and attentive. His razor-sharp claws, wielded with great strength and precision, are his chief weapons, yet he can also wield weapons of human devising with extraordinary skill.

Like all higher vampires, Dettlaff can turn into fog and envelop opponents. When fighting a vampire in this form, one must watch out for magic puddles and attacks from the air. When wounded, Detlaff tends to assume his winged form, using these powerful appendages to stun his foes near effortlessly.

One must remember higher vampires are immortal creatures and thus do not fear for their lives while fighting, meaning they take every risk. They are able to turn invisible and can regenerate strength during combat. All in all, they are supremely difficult foes, even for a witcher.
Dettlaff van der Eretein
Hello-ee!
Hiya!
Mhm?
I've heard of you.
Hahahahahahahahahaha…
Now, now.
Why do you need the sword?
Rape!
Sir de Peyrac-Peyran rides no more… Some knight.
Agh. How do I muster the strength for it all?
Yet again they'll drink, yet again they'll soil the carpets…
Yes? What is it?
I'm busy.
{Hwer Beauclair, y hwer Nilfgaard.} [Beauclair and Nilfgaard - what's to compare?]
{Ech, alz esse'fan heer gu brài…} [Ehh, if I could only stay here forever…]
You were saying?
Mhm, what, what?

One could put forward the brashly contrarian thesis that a stay in a prison would be a welcome change for a witcher. I know, I know, but bear with me: remember, a witcher spends his entire life, or at least a good part of it, wandering around trackless wildernesses and sleeping with no shelter but a hedgerow or a few bare branches. Therefore, a penal institution, which by definition will have walls, and most likely a roof as well, will at least protect him from strong winds, unexpected morning rains and the droppings of passing birds. Ergo, it would present an upgrade in terms of comfort… though at the price of a downgrade in terms of freedom.

While becoming intimately acquainted with the charms of prison life, Geralt found a secret stash, used by inmates for purposes of trade.

The witcher puzzled out what to do to use the stash to make a trade. A certain fellow inmate greatly desired a hammer and chisel, having had enough of the prison’s hospitality and wishing to take his leave of the establishment. Geralt placed these objects in the stash, and in return received… a placard.
A very interesting placard, in fact. An object of great desire in its own right.
Geralt decided he did not care to check how much a hammer and chisel could fetch in prison currency.
Search for a hammer and chisel.
Hide the hammer and chisel in the stash.
Wait seven days.
Check the prison stash.
Read the notes.
The Perks of Being a Jailbird
Count Beledal
Regards, mate.
Always good, meetin' a professional.
Fetch this, empty that, sweep up here… Botch it all!
Boy, is my bum ever ready to blow.
Find yourself some work!
I've no time now.
Tam ta ra ra ra ra tum…
Clang! Clang! Clangity! Clang!
Salutations!
Well, well, well… Heard you waged war against the vampires. Chapeau bas, witcher.
Hammer, anvil - bammity, bam! Music to a smithie's ears!
With a heft of my hammer and a mighty cry, I pound steel and watch sparks fly!
Careful, there!
Calm, now! Calm!
Lebioda's wounds! Geralt of Rivia!
Help! Help us!
Someone! Please! Help!
Wha?
I'd kill for a bite.
*Spits* Fuck all this.
Your time to die.
Sheathe the sword, mate.
You bored, mate?!
Good of you to behave, mate.
Pth. Come on, then.
Earth Elemental
No, he did not.
Gareth broke his vow, failed to stay faithful.
Man is built of mud and filth, m'Lady. And is like to blunder, we all are.
How cruel is the world to render conferring one's love so hard.
But what would the world be without love?
No "happily-ever-afters" in life.
Happily ever after doesn't often happen in life. Sadly.
You did well. Here, your pay. And the book is yours, as well.
Thanks. Take care of yourself.
So long, witcher. I must think, put this straight in my head.
We did all we could.
Did what we could.
The time comes that I depart. I've waited too long, I've suffered too much, and now I wish to go.
Farewell, m'Lady.
I thank you, stranger.
And you, my knight. I thank you for speaking to me, for standing vigil at my feet.
I did not think it would end this way. I hoped we could revive her, but I guess it was not to be.
Gareth remained faithful to the end of his days.
Gareth remained faithful.
Behold a bone of he to whom you offered your love.
Gareth, my Gareth. He shall never return.
No. He won't.
Is his love for me gone? Did he stay true?
Dammit… Run!
Hear me, you who hide beneath this bark! The day of your freedom has come!
Behold a kerchief, proof of your love for another.
Hear me, you who hide beneath this bark! Recall today who you really are!
Behold a kerchief, proof of your love for another.
You've been to Zerrikania?!
Ofier - have you been there?!
Lebioda's wheezing lungs! A real witcher!
Witcher!
Found your things.
Splendid! Where were they? And… hm, is this all you found? I left so much more.
Should've kept it all with you, not left it lying around. Followed some paint tracks to a nekker lair. Seems the beasts made off with your supplies.
Used it to paint a fresco on one of the cave walls. Looked something like a… battle scene to me.
Impossible. They splashed paint on the wall in a rage. Unimportant. In any case, it's a good thing you found the basic colors.
